It's unclear if other governments, including the UK's GCHQ, have used Prism, or if other nations are involved. The EU Justice Commission expressed concern over the implications for EU citizens.

Despite assurances from officials, privacy concerns persist. Snowden, the leaker, expressed his fears about living in a society with such extensive surveillance, stating he didn't want "everything I do and say is recorded." Privacy International echoed these concerns, noting that users of popular US-based services could have their privacy compromised through Prism.

OpenAI, a new venture backed by prominent figures such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to conduct AI research with a focus on positive human impact, free from financial obligations. Despite warnings from scientists, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, about the potential existential threat AI could pose to humanity, OpenAI asserts that the risk of misuse remains remote. The organization emphasizes the potential of AI to greatly benefit society, but also acknowledges the danger of incorrect development or use. OpenAI's mission is to advance digital intelligence in a way that benefits humanity as a whole, rather than for financial gain. They envision AI as an extension of individual human wills, to be distributed as broadly and safely as possible. Only a small portion of the $1 billion pledged will be spent in the near future.

L/Bdr Ben Parkinson, a seriously injured British soldier from Doncaster, carried the Olympic torch on June 26, 2012, following a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006 that left him with a brain injury, loss of speech, but preserved personality and humor. Despite his injuries, he has shown remarkable determination, spending 12 hours daily in gym and rehab, and walking with crutches. His nomination highlighted his unchanged intelligence and wit. 

Parkinson's torch-carrying event sparked an overwhelming response on Facebook, with thousands of friend requests, surpassing the platform's limit of 5,000 per personal page. His mother, Diane, reported phenomenal support, with over 19,000 hits on his page update and numerous messages of encouragement. The family has also received an increased volume of mail and emails.

Parkinson is actively involved in raising funds for military charities and serves as a patron for his beloved Pilgrim Bandits. Facebook suggested he consider transitioning to a public page or using the'subscribe' feature to manage the high volume of requests. 

The Olympic torch relay, covering 8,000 miles over 70 days, will involve 8,000 torchbearers, culminating in the opening ceremony of the London Olympic Games on July 27, 2012.

In 2011, the U.S. poverty rate remained steady at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. This followed three consecutive years of increases. The real median income for households decreased by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as gauged by the Gini index, saw a significant rise of 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. Despite this, the percentage of uninsured Americans dropped slightly from 16.3% to 15.7%. Notably, poverty had reached a record high of 15.1% in 2010.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, signed a new contract with Lancashire, extending his stay until 2019. He previously moved to Lancashire from Somerset in 2013. Buttler is recognized as a short-format specialist, having scored England's three fastest One Day International (ODI) centuries, including a remarkable 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised Buttler's talent, noting his significant contribution to Lancashire's T20 Blast victory last year. Giles also highlighted Buttler's positive influence in the dressing room and the value of his international experience. Buttler, who has been participating in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, is set to return to Lancashire for their upcoming T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to express interest in these former Devonport-based ships. As of now, no proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Those who have registered interest are finalizing their bids, with viewings scheduled for late February and March. A final decision is anticipated in the spring.

The UK's Disposal Services Authority, managing the sale, aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the UK's recycling industry capacity. Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports this approach but also advocates for preserving at least one ship, possibly converting it into a reef or diving attraction to honor its service and potentially generate tourism income.

The Type 22 frigates, originally anti-submarine vessels, evolved into versatile surface combatants with robust anti-surface, anti-submarine, and anti-aircraft systems, along with excellent command and control capabilities. They typically had a crew of around 280. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3 million, setting a precedent for the current frigates' potential disposal. The Ministry of Defence is considering all options to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers, though specifics on received bids remain undisclosed due to commercial sensitivity.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced recurring racial and political tensions, leading to four coups in 20 years. The first, in 1987, was led by indigenous Fijians and overthrew an Indian-dominated coalition, followed by the introduction and withdrawal of a constitution favoring indigenous supremacy. In 2000, businessman George Speight led another coup, holding the first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet hostage for weeks. These events severely damaged Fiji's economy, particularly tourism, and its international standing. The 2000 coup's aftermath was marked by persistent divisions over amnesty, culminating in a 2006 military takeover. Fiji was suspended from the Commonwealth in 2009 due to lack of democratic progress, only the second such suspension in the organization's history. The suspension was lifted in 2014 after Fiji agreed to hold free elections, which it did, restoring diplomatic ties with Australia, New Zealand, and the Commonwealth.

Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, descendants of Indian laborers. The latter, once roughly equal in number to indigenous Fijians, have been reduced due to emigration following the coups. Indigenous Fijians now form a slight majority. The two groups are largely segregated, with minimal intermarriage. Other minorities include Chinese and Rotumans.

Economically, Fiji depends heavily on sugar and tourism for foreign exchange, but also has mining (gold, silver, limestone), a robust services sector, and light manufacturing. Despite this diversity, Fiji faces significant trade and budget deficits, making it one of the world's largest per capita aid recipients.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated to the BBC that Syria is making efforts to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timeline, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Two shipments were sent, with the second one reportedly intercepted by fire from "terrorist groups" en route from Damascus to Latakia. Mekdad emphasized the challenges posed by the ongoing war, urging the U.S. and others to consider this context.

He strongly criticized U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims has killed 246 people, including 73 children, in the past five days. The Aleppo Media Centre reported 14 deaths from recent barrel bomb attacks in Masaken Hanano district.

Mekdad denied these allegations, asserting that Syria is defending against "terrorist attacks" and has never targeted civilian areas. He accused the U.S. of supporting "terrorist elements" within the country. 

Regarding the central prison in Aleppo, state media denied rebel control, while activist groups reported that the Islamic Front coalition, including al-Nusra Front, had seized it, freeing hundreds of detainees. The prison is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees in poor conditions.

Syria possesses about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% (30 tonnes) reportedly exported as per the U.S. Last week. The U.S. and Russia have expressed concerns over the slow progress of the UN-backed plan, with Russia setting a new deadline of 1 March for the transfer of all weapons to the coast for removal by ship. The OPCW, overseeing the destruction, has cited security concerns for the delays. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council, promising to meet all obligations on time.

The 2014 Booker Prize shortlist, now in its 46th year, includes six authors from various English-speaking nations. The frontrunner is Indian author Neel Mukherjee for his novel "The Lives of Others," set in 1960s Calcutta, focusing on family secrets and political activism. This year, the prize is open to all English-language writers, regardless of nationality. Other nominees include British authors Howard Jacobson and Ali Smith, Americans Joshua Ferris and Karen Joy Fowler, and Australian Richard Flanagan. 

Jacobson, a former Booker winner, is nominated for his futuristic love story "J," set in a world where the past is taboo. Smith's "How To Be Two" interweaves stories from 15th Century Italy and the 1960s. Ferris' "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour" explores atheism through a New York dentist's perspective. Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" narrates a family's story with a surprising twist, and Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North" is a World War II love story set against the backdrop of the Thailand-Burma Death Railway.

Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" is the best-selling among the shortlisted novels, having sold over 55,000 copies since March. The shortlist announcement caused a sales spike for all nominated books. The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall and will receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. The judging panel, chaired by AC Grayling, includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing to the UK Supreme Court against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on naming him in media publications in England and Wales. The case revolves around allegations of his extra-marital activities, which were first reported to The Sun on Sunday. These activities, involving a woman named AB, began in 2009 and included a three-way encounter with AB's partner, CD. Despite a High Court judge initially refusing to impose an injunction, the appeal court later ruled in PJS's favor, preventing his identification in English and Welsh publications. However, News Group Newspapers, publishers of The Sun on Sunday, successfully appealed this decision in the Court of Appeal.

The Court of Appeal judges ruled that PJS was unlikely to secure a permanent injunction, as details of the allegations had become "so widespread" that confidentiality was likely lost. They noted that while PJS's legal team had been diligent in removing breaches of the injunction from the internet, the task had become "hopeless". An interim injunction remains in place until the Supreme Court hearing, preventing any publication that could reveal PJS's identity before 13:00 BST on Wednesday. The Supreme Court will now decide whether to grant PJS's appeal and, if so, whether to allow or dismiss it. PJS argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action to protect his identity.

Fosse Park, located near M1 junction 21 and opened in 1989, was recently purchased for £345.5 million. The new owners, represented by Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, aim to enhance the park's appearance, address parking and traffic congestion issues, and improve the quality of common areas. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, noted that the new owners view Fosse Park as a significant investment and a gateway to the city. Currently, the park's appearance is described as tired and lacking aesthetic appeal, with an overabundance of shed backs visible. The new owners are committed to making Fosse Park a better-quality retail destination.

The live-action remake of Disney's "Beauty and the Beast" has caused controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" featured in the film. Initially scheduled for release on a Thursday, Disney announced a content review, leading to a delay. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit concerning this scene. Homosexuality is illegal in Malaysia, a Muslim-majority country, though the nation's tourism minister deemed banning the film as "ridiculous". The film was given a "P13 parental guidance classification". LPF Chairman Datuk Abdul Hamid clarified that while they approve content, the actual screening date and venue are not under their jurisdiction. Local cinema chains have started offering refunds for pre-purchased tickets. The controversial scene involves LeFou, Gaston's sidekick, grappling with feelings for Gaston. This decision to review the film sparked criticism from the public, with many deeming it "stupid and laughable", and highlighting perceived inconsistencies in censorship standards.

Southampton City Council requires landlords renting properties to more than three unrelated individuals to obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs??1,000. However, many landlords avoid this due to the cost, despite potential fines of up to??20,000. The council estimates around 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Mandatory HMO licensing applies nationally to houses of three or more stories occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, this affects properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1), and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2). Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan reports frequent tenant concerns about eviction and poor maintenance in unregulated rented homes due to a shortage of affordable housing. While most landlords comply, a minority resists obtaining the licence. The council has secured prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil are striving to prevent a second election. Martin has indicated that his party will facilitate a minority government but won't endorse a programme for government. Water charges are a significant obstacle in reaching an agreement. A commission to review the future of Irish Water, the national water utility, is under consideration. Fianna Fáil advocates for the immediate abolition of water charges, while Fine Gael believes they should persist. Post the election, Fine Gael secured 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party 7. However, no party managed to form a majority government, and TDs have not yet elected a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ship en route to Valencia, caught fire approximately 27km from Mallorca on Tuesday afternoon. The blaze rapidly escalated, prompting the evacuation of passengers onto lifeboats. At least three individuals sustained injuries, one of them seriously, and were airlifted to a hospital. The cause of the fire remains unknown. Multiple ships, including two passenger ferries, responded to the distress call. The evacuated passengers were transferred to the ferry Puglia. The Sorrento, potentially at risk of sinking, was abandoned by its crew. The rescued passengers were expected to return to Palma de Mallorca's port within a few hours. Psychological support was being arranged for the arriving passengers. The distress signal was issued at 13:50 local time (11:50 GMT) by the Italian-owned ferry Puglia. Initially, the captain deemed abandonment unnecessary, but the fire's intensity necessitated a full evacuation.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs flagged instances of potential voter fraud, with individuals, including students, allegedly voting twice, a criminal offense. A record 46.8 million people were registered to vote in the June 8 election, a 500,000 increase from 2015 and surpassing the 46.4 million who voted in the EU referendum. The turnout was 68.7%, the highest since 1997. There was a surge in voter registration applications following Theresa May's announcement of the snap poll and before the May 22 deadline, totaling 2.9 million. Constituencies with large student populations, like Canterbury and Cambridge, saw electorate increases of over 10%.

However, concerns persist about duplicate applications, a problem that emerged post-EU referendum. The current system lacks a direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service, leading to potential duplicate entries. Between December 2016 and May 22, 4.9 million applications were submitted, but the net increase in electoral register entries was only 1.4 million, suggesting a high proportion of duplicates (30-70%). This has imposed significant administrative and financial burdens on electoral officials.

The Electoral Commission proposed clearer information on registration sites, possibly including a verification function, as used in Australia, New Zealand, and the Republic of Ireland. Despite efforts to discourage duplicate registrations, many people submitted multiple applications due to the ease of online registration versus the difficulty of checking with local authorities. Although there's no concrete evidence of widespread double voting, the Commission emphasized the seriousness of the issue and urged reporting to the police.

Labour's shadow minister, Cat Smith, stressed that while voting twice is a serious offense, any solution must not inadvertently hinder young or student voters who legitimately need to register at multiple addresses due to work or study. She warned against a knee-jerk reaction that could disproportionately affect these groups.

Lawrence Phillips, aged 40, is believed to have taken his own life on Wednesday. In the 1990s, he was a prominent player at the University of Nebraska, leading him to a successful NFL career with the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers. However, his professional football career was marred by numerous off-field issues. Post-NFL, Phillips faced repeated legal troubles, including convictions for assault - one for driving into a group of teenagers and another for assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a lengthy prison sentence, having been isolated in a cell alone following an accusation of killing his cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge recently ruled there was sufficient evidence to try Phillips in Soward's death. Despite his intelligence and positive traits, Phillips struggled with anger issues and personal demons, as noted by his former coach, Tom Osborne.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to his rank at an event in Chester, marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment. The promotion, given for "good behaviour", was bestowed by Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the regiment. Derby XXX is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the Indian Mutiny War in the mid-19th Century. Originally acquired by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot in 1858, he became the Mercian Regiment's mascot upon its formation in 2007. Derby XXX joined the regiment in February 2014, complete with his own army number and pay for rations. He takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. His roles have included switching on Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at a memorial unveiling for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool secured a dramatic 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund in the Europa League, advancing to the semi-finals and moving closer to a Champions League spot. The match, played at Anfield, was marked by intense emotion, excitement, and brilliant football. Dortmund took an early 2-0 lead, but Liverpool, inspired by manager Jurgen Klopp's invocation of the 2005 Istanbul comeback, staged a remarkable turnaround. Goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and a late header from Dejan Lovren sealed the win. Klopp, known for his energetic touchline presence, emphasized the importance of turning doubters into believers, a theme that resonated throughout the match. The victory underscores Klopp's impact on the team in just six months, imprinting his identity and fostering a belief in his players and fans. Despite the win, the passage notes some defensive vulnerabilities, particularly with Alberto Moreno and Mamadou Sakho. The win, reminiscent of the 2005 Istanbul comeback, has instilled confidence in Liverpool, making them favorites to progress in the Europa League and potentially return to the Champions League.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK ministers discussed their approach to Brexit negotiations with the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. David Davis, the UK's Brexit Secretary, proposed monthly meetings to share analysis and maintain a "two-way information flow," aiming to incorporate the devolved administrations' perspectives in shaping the UK's negotiating strategy. Davis emphasized the importance of collaboration and constructive dialogue, stating that the meeting was an essential step towards securing the best deal for the entire UK.

However, Scotland's Cabinet Secretary, Rhodri Morgan Russell, expressed the need for greater transparency regarding the UK government's strategic intentions. He criticized the lack of clarity on whether the UK aims to remain in the single market or customs union, which he deemed crucial for Scotland's economic prosperity. Russell also announced that the Scottish government intends to oppose the UK government's appeal in the Supreme Court regarding the triggering of Article 50, with Scotland's Lord Advocate, James Wolffe, set to argue the case.

In summary, while the UK government seeks to involve the devolved administrations in Brexit negotiations, there remains a call for more transparency and clarity from Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland regarding the UK's strategic plans. The Scottish government, in particular, is committed to challenging the UK's approach in the Supreme Court.

Dr. Sandra Corr, a veterinary surgeon, conducts a physical examination on Daisy, a cloned sheep, checking for signs of heat, swelling, crepitus, or lameness, which could indicate disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is part of a flock of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, four of which (Daisy, Debbie, Denise, and Diane) were cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal born in 1996. These four sheep are considered "identical twin sisters" to Dolly.

The sheep undergo rigorous tests, including joint manipulations and X-rays, to assess their health and aging process. The study, led by Professor Kevin Sinclair, aims to address concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" into the cloned animals, causing premature aging and associated diseases. Dolly, the original cloned sheep, died at six-and-a-half years old, suffering from osteoarthritis and lung lesions, raising questions about the health of cloned animals.

The research focuses on three age-related conditions: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. Despite their age (approaching nine and ten years), the cloned sheep, known as the "dollies," appear to be in good health. The results of this study, which could significantly impact the future of cloning, are set to be published soon.

In a race at Newmarket, trainer John Gosden's unbeaten 4-7 favorite, Shutter Speed, won by a length and three quarters, beating Vintage Folly. Despite the soft ground making it "hard work" for her, jockey Frankie Dettori praised her performance, noting her class and potential on better ground. Shutter Speed will head to Chantilly for the Oaks, while stablemates Enable and Coronet are favored for the Epsom Oaks. 

Meanwhile, William Haggas' Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, comfortably beating Magical Memory and Comicas. 

Gosden expressed concern about the ground conditions for his colt Cracksman in the upcoming Dante Stakes, and will decide on his participation after walking the course. The close proximity of the Dante Stakes to the Derby (16 days apart) may lead to Cracksman skipping the Dante. BBC Sport's Cornelius Lysaght highlighted Shutter Speed's good form and her ability to handle the soggy conditions.

The passage discusses the fluctuation of the British pound in the lead-up to the EU referendum. Initially, the pound weakened against the dollar, euro, and yen, but later recovered slightly before falling again. The "volatility index," a gauge of investor uncertainty, reached levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis, indicating heightened market anxiety. Polls suggest a tight race between the Leave and Remain camps, with two recent polls showing the Leave campaign in the lead. Betting firm Betfair reported a drop in the implied probability of a Remain vote from nearly 80% to 68.5% over a week.

Financial experts predict increased volatility in the pound as new polls are released, with hedge funds reportedly betting on further sterling depreciation. The uncertainty has also impacted global markets, causing a significant fall in Asian stock markets, including Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's main index. The London FTSE 100 also experienced a decline, ending the day 1.1% lower.

Nigel Farage, a Leave campaigner, argued that the pound has strengthened since March and that a weaker currency benefits UK exporters, a claim supported by recent official figures showing a narrowed UK trade deficit due to increased exports.

Braintree Town, referred to as 'The Iron', are currently in sixth place in the National League, just one point and position away from the play-off spots. Despite losing to Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games, manager Cowley expressed positive sentiments. He acknowledged the difficulty of the match, noting that Barrow's early goal compounded challenges exacerbated by a long travel journey. Cowley praised his team's performance, describing their overall achievement as "remarkable". He emphasized the unique nature of their part-time status, calling this season's challenge their toughest yet. However, he remains optimistic, stating they will embrace and enjoy the challenge.

From April 2015, Northern Ireland's planning system will undergo a significant shift, transferring the responsibility of approving or rejecting development proposals from the Planning Service to local councils. This change aims to democratize the planning process, allowing elected politicians to make decisions on local developments. Michael Corr, from PLACE, views this as a positive opportunity for councils to create community-focused development plans, emphasizing the need for politicians skilled in urban regeneration and planning.

However, this move is not without controversy. Historically, local councils in Northern Ireland have faced accusations of discrimination in public housing allocation, as seen in the 1960s Civil Rights movement protests. Environmental group Friends of the Earth express concerns about potential unfairness and lack of transparency, warning of a possible return to biased planning permissions. They stress the importance of a strict code of conduct and increased transparency to prevent politicking and favoritism.

Additionally, there are worries about the close relationships between developers and political parties, fearing a lax system that might bypass proper democratic planning. Friends of the Earth also advocate for disclosure of political donations, arguing that with increased political powers and financial implications, public knowledge of donors is crucial. Some local politicians oppose the change, citing potential threats to donor security, while others argue that the £7,500 donation limit is insignificant for Northern Ireland's political parties. The decision on when to implement greater transparency in political donations lies with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie survived being shot three times - twice in the shoulder and once in her left back leg, which had to be amputated. The incident occurred on March 14, 2022, in Niddry View, Winchburgh, when her owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured. Teenie is currently learning to walk again. The Scottish SPCA described the attack as "cruel" and emphasized the danger, especially given the proximity to a housing estate with children. Scottish SPCA Ch Supt Mike Flynn called for urgent implementation of airgun licensing, citing the incident as a reason. Last year, the Scottish government proposed licensing air weapons, but a majority (87%) of respondents opposed the plan, deeming it "draconian" and "heavy-handed". The proposed scheme would require owners to prove a legitimate reason for owning an air gun. The Scottish SPCA is urging anyone with information about the incident to come forward to the authorities.

Liverpool has signed Belgian striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa for a reported fee, making him the club's second most expensive signing. The 24-year-old, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, signed a long-term contract with Liverpool after the club triggered a release clause in his contract. Benteke expressed his happiness about joining Liverpool, stating his desire to win trophies and contribute to the team's goals.

This signing comes after Liverpool's struggle with goal-scoring last season, following the departure of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge, which led to a sixth-place finish in the Premier League. To address this issue, Liverpool has made several summer signings, including Benteke, Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and the return of Divock Origi.

Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury, returned to action in October 2014 and scored 15 goals to help Villa avoid relegation and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and ex-Liverpool striker John Aldridge are optimistic about Benteke's potential at Anfield, praising his strength, speed, and goal-scoring ability. Aldridge believes Benteke will bring a new dimension to Liverpool's attack, which managed only eight goals last season.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools and led by Barbie Clarke, examines the use of tablet devices in 671 state and independent schools. It reveals that while tablets are increasingly prevalent, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them, there's no clear evidence of improved academic performance linked to their use. The study found that 9% of schools provide a tablet for each pupil, with academy schools showing the highest usage. The number of tablets in schools is projected to rise from 430,000 to nearly 900,000 between 2014 and 2016.

Despite the lack of definitive academic improvement link, head teachers report positive impacts, such as increased motivation for disengaged pupils and greater family involvement when students take tablets home. The study also highlights the deep integration of technology in young people's lives, with a quarter of secondary pupils in schools where every pupil has a tablet describing themselves as "internet addicts". About two-thirds take devices to bed for social media or video watching.

Simon Mason, head of Honywood Community School, advocates for tablet use, noting their portability and relevance to modern life. He believes tablets foster a sense of empowerment among students and create a trusting, valued environment. While the specific benefits are hard to quantify, Mason emphasizes the importance of schools functioning in line with the contemporary world. A separate study from the National Literacy Trust and Pearson suggests touch-screen computers, in particular, can aid boys and poorer pupils in learning to read, with children from poorer backgrounds more likely to read on touch-screen devices than printed books.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool showcases 25 photographs spanning over 100 years, from the 1880s to the 1990s. These images provide a nostalgic look into the lives of children in Liverpool, illustrating changes in childhood experiences and marking special occasions on the city's streets. The oldest photo, from 1887, features the Rollo children dressed for a fancy dress ball hosted by Bootle's Mayor and Mayoress. Another image from around 1900 captures a young maid, highlighting the reality of child labor. Curator Kay Jones carefully selected these images from the National Museums Liverpool's collections to represent a comprehensive range of childhood experiences, both positive and challenging. The exhibition aims to evoke memories of street play while also acknowledging the harsher realities of childhood in the past. It is open at the Museum of Liverpool until 25th September.

Centre-back Anderson, a 27-year-old former player for Aldershot, Exeter, and Italian clubs, has mutually agreed to terminate his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He might play against his previous club, Barrow, on 28 February. Additionally, Torquay United (Gulls) have signed 21-year-old striker Keating, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has experience with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Torquay's manager, Kevin Nicholson, described Anderson as a leader with potential despite limited game time for his age, and Keating as young, raw but eager to prove himself. Torquay currently sits four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six matches.

Bolivia's new legislation, approved and signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent. This law reflects Bolivia's economic reality, where over 500,000 children already work to support their families, often in sectors like shoe cleaning and food sales. However, many face harsher conditions in mining and agriculture. The law also imposes severe penalties, including a 30-year jail term for child homicide, aiming to protect children's rights. The government, led by the socialist party, hopes this law will aid in eradicating extreme poverty. Despite aligning with the International Labour Organisation's (ILO) minimum working age of 14 for developing countries, the law has raised concerns about potential breaches of international child labor regulations, which the ILO is currently reviewing.

50-year-old actress Kate O'Donnell, known for her roles in shows like Drop Dead Diva, Will and Grace, and Nip/Tuck, survived a "widow maker" heart attack. She fell ill at home with chest pain, nausea, and fever after helping a woman. O'Donnell researched her symptoms online, identifying them as potential heart attack signs, and self-medicated with aspirin. The next day, a cardiologist found her artery 99% blocked and inserted a stent. Despite not calling emergency services, O'Donnell used her blog to warn women about the symptoms and urged them to listen to their bodies and call 911. She recently hosted The Rosie Show, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 16-year-old from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway near a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, Kent, around 00:30 GMT on Saturday. The incident occurred after a group of youths, who had been denied entry to the party, engaged in a fight. Che was not involved in the initial altercation but was targeted later. Another 16-year-old boy was also stabbed at the party and is in stable condition at a north London hospital. The party was described as well-managed with adult supervision. Detective Chief Inspector Chris Jones is seeking witnesses who were in the alleyway between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time of the stabbing. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, while two boys aged 15 and 16, and a 14-year-old have been arrested and bailed under investigation.

Denmark implemented a new diagnostic approach for cancer patients, particularly those with vague or hard-to-diagnose symptoms, following poor cancer survival statistics compared to other European countries. The changes, inspired by a visit to Aarhus, Denmark, introduced three diagnostic routes. 

1. For patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers, there are fast-track diagnosis and treatment routes with strict time targets.
2. By law, any patient with a physical illness must be investigated within 30 days of a GP referral.
3. Diagnosis centers were established where patients with undiagnosed symptoms receive quick tests and scans.
4. "Yes-no" centers offer simple tests or scans for patients with minor symptoms, ensuring quick identification of any serious issues.

These changes have improved the organization of patient diagnoses within existing resources, leading to better survival rates. Denmark is now closing the gap with top-performing European countries like Norway, Sweden, and Finland. The model could provide valuable lessons for Wales, emphasizing the importance of collaboration between GPs and specialists in improving cancer diagnosis and patient outcomes.

Powys County Council has been selected to manage a new service that will enforce estate agent laws and issue warnings or bans against dishonest agents. This role comes after the UK government disbanded the Office of Fair Trading (OFT). Powys won a competitive bidding process and will receive an annual fee of £170,000 for this service. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders if needed. However, these departments will refer cases involving breaches of the Estate Agents Act to Powys. James Munro, from Powys Council, expressed hope that this new responsibility could lead to more contracts and external work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan, following a Nuffield Trust review, to redefine roles within the NHS workforce to address staffing shortages. The review found instances of nurses stepping in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs, indicating potential for broader role expansion. This proposal aims to leverage the 1.3 million-strong workforce, particularly nurses, to cover gaps in junior doctor rotas and manage the increasing patient load in GP surgeries. The changing nature of care, with a greater focus on managing long-term conditions, supports this reshaping. 

The Nuffield Trust report highlights "huge opportunities" for enhancing patient care and job satisfaction among staff. However, unions like the British Medical Association and Unison caution against using this as a quick fix. They emphasize the need for continued quality training for doctors and adequate funding for staff development, warning that the current funding squeeze in the NHS could hinder such initiatives. NHS Employers' chief executive, Danny Mortimer, acknowledges the challenge of implementing the report's recommendations.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath, specifically at Rackfield Place near the First depot, following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The road closure, which lasted until 14:00 GMT, led to significant disruptions and delays for commuters and bus services during peak hours. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, the bus company, reported that while some services have resumed normal schedules, it may take a few more hours for all services to return to normal. James Freeman, the managing director, expressed hope for a full service by the evening commute. He also thanked the public for their support and staff for their extraordinary efforts in managing the situation and recovery.

The passage discusses a dispute between Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) regarding the environmental impact of the £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project. NRW estimated that 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout would die annually due to the lagoon, as these species migrate to and from local rivers. However, TLP disputed these figures, stating they lack a "clear scientific basis" and accused NRW of refusing to share its methodology. TLP's computer modeling suggested a "worst-case scenario" of 2% of all fish species being affected. 

The project, seen as a test for larger versions in other Welsh locations, is under review by UK government ministers. Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths expressed support for the scheme but emphasized the need for clarity from the UK government soon. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism, asserting they've shared extensive data and methodology with TLP over a year-and-a-half, and are confident their estimates are based on the best available evidence for environmental protection.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster announced the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, modeled after Scotland's successful Food and Drink entity. This initiative aims to leverage the sector's strength, which employs nearly 100,000 people across farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The body, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB), will provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill endorsed the move, highlighting the agri-food sector's crucial role in driving export-led economic growth. O'Neill noted that industry representatives had emphasized the need for improved coordination in current marketing efforts. While she viewed the new body positively, she also acknowledged potential implications for her department and other organizations, expressing her intention to discuss these matters with the AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a significant tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, taking place on a Saturday afternoon. This project is part of a four-year, nationwide initiative aiming to plant millions of native UK trees to honor the millions who died in WW1. Specifically, 40,000 trees will be planted in Brackfield Wood to commemorate the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The project, using the slogan "We will stand for those who fell," invites local residents and visitors to participate in planting these saplings, provided by the charity. The goal is to create a thriving wildlife habitat with carpets of wildflowers, including poppies, by the project's end. Patrick Cregg, the director of the Woodland Trust, encourages community involvement, emphasizing the trees' role as a lasting tribute to the Irish who contributed to the war. The event is located about seven miles from Derry city, off the Glenshane Road, with limited parking available. Participants are advised to wear welly boots or sturdy footwear.

Hilary Mantel won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin" at the Harrogate crime writing festival. The book, a thriller dealing with domestic violence and honour crime, is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. Judge Alison Graham praised it as "an emotionally exhausting and powerful story", while Ann Cleeves, this year's festival chair, commended its finely written and tightly plotted nature. 

Sara Paretsky, the US author known for creating detective VI Warshawski, was honored with an award for outstanding contribution to crime fiction. Paretsky's 23-year career has been marked by her strong female protagonist, VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago, who was a significant shift in the genre. Cleeves highlighted that Warshawski was "a real game changer", influencing readers' perceptions of female writers and protagonists. Paretsky also founded Sisters In Crime, an organization supporting female crime writers globally.

New Zealand cricketer Mitchell Santner, aged 24, will return to Worcestershire County Cricket Club next summer following an injury in 2016. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, broke his finger in his second game for the county, which was a significant setback. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed that losing Santner was a major blow to their chances of qualifying last season. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, enjoyed his time at Worcester and is eager to make up for the lost time. He aims to contribute both with his batting and bowling. In August, Worcestershire had signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a staged hit-and-run accident in Kiev, Ukraine, in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina (known as Anna), was 19 years his junior. She had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove when Pring was struck by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway. The car had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. Coroner Dr. Elizabeth Earland at Exeter County Hall recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that Pring's inebriation lowered his guard. The evidence, much of it circumstantial, was deemed overwhelming.

Pring's family suspects foul play, believing Anna orchestrated the incident to inherit his assets. They claim she was a lap dancer and stripper, not a teacher as she claimed when they met online in 2006. The couple married four days after meeting in 2007. Post-Pring's death, Anna sold his Range Rover, emptied his flat, and moved funds from his bank account. She was entitled to the first £200,000 of his estate and was reportedly having an affair with a Ukrainian man.

The inquest heard that Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it in 2011 as a murder inquiry, though it remains inactive. Anna did not attend the inquest, citing she had provided statements to Ukrainian police and saw no need to add further information. Detective Constable Jonathan Watts confirmed the car was speeding at 75mph with no lights and that witnesses described the act as deliberate. The case has caused prolonged distress for Pring's family.

Sophie Fearns, from Merseyside, UK, is seeking to fly her son Charlie, who has been ill since age three, to Seattle, America for experimental T-Cell Therapy. This treatment is unavailable in the UK and is crucial as a previous transplant failed. After a third relapse in April, the family found no further treatment options in the UK. An anonymous donor has generously offered to cover the costs of Charlie's treatment at Seattle Children's Hospital, leaving the family "ecstatic" and "overwhelmed". The hospital has confirmed the financial clearance, and Charlie's treatment is set to commence as soon as possible, with the exact date expected to be confirmed next week.

The passage discusses a security vulnerability in Apple's iCloud service that led to the theft of intimate celebrity photos, allegedly through third-party software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. Apple has since implemented a two-step verification process to prevent unauthorized access. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code texted to a trusted device or sent via Apple's Find My iPhone app after inputting their username and password on a new device. If the code isn't entered, users are blocked from making purchases on iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store, though they can use a 14-character recovery key to regain access.

The two-step verification was previously optional for iCloud, but not for other Apple services. Now, it applies to iCloud backups, closing a loophole that allowed hackers to access complete data backups even with correct passwords. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed his software was used in the hacks but acknowledged Apple's changes make his tool ineffective.

However, concerns remain. Elcomsoft's owner noted the recovery key could be lost or stolen, potentially causing significant issues. Another security expert, Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, advocated for two-factor authentication to be the default setting, not just a recommendation, across tech companies including Apple, Microsoft, and Google. Apple has stated it plans to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, recognizing the need to improve user awareness of security measures.

Billericay Town Football Club is currently in negotiations for a deal where Joe Wright, a 30-year-old former non-league player and I'm A Celebrity runner-up, is set to acquire a 20% stake in the club. Wright is expected to assume the role of a club director. Billericay currently stands eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just three points behind a play-off spot. Wright has a history of playing for various non-league clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club was recently taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has pledged to invest £10,000 weekly into the team. Notably, Billericay signed former England international Paul Konchesky, aged 35, at the beginning of March.

Mr. Ashley, the owner of Sports Direct and Newcastle United Football Club, has been requested to provide evidence regarding the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse practices in Derbyshire. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, gave Mr. Ashley until 21 March to respond. The committee is particularly interested in the treatment of low-paid workers and the enforcement of the national minimum wage. Despite inviting the committee to a public meeting at the Shirebrook base, Mr. Ashley has not accepted any of the proposed dates, nor agreed in principle to attend. The letter from Mr. Wright warns that if Mr. Ashley does not comply, the committee may escalate the matter, potentially seeking support from the House of Commons for contempt. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request for a response, but the company has previously committed to reviewing worker rights with Mr. Ashley's oversight.

The passage discusses a report, initially started by murdered Russian opposition politician Boris Nemtsov and completed by his colleagues, accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine. The report, titled "Putin. War," compiles facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in March 2014 and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. It asserts that Russian soldiers and equipment were crucial to the pro-Russian rebels' major victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, despite Russia's denial of sending regular troops, claiming they are "volunteers."

The report includes evidence from volunteer soldiers admitting to being directed by Russian generals and receiving substantial salaries. It estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53 billion roubles (approximately $1 billion). The document also documents names and photos of weaponry, though verification is challenging without knowing their origin.

The report's completion and distribution have been difficult due to fear among potential collaborators following Nemtsov's assassination. Despite this, the opposition plans to seek donations to extend the initial print run of 2,000 copies. The report's release comes amid differing Russian public perceptions: while many are aware of Russia's involvement, they may view it as support for separatists seeking independence from Kiev. However, the opposition accuses Putin of orchestrating the war to bolster his declining popularity, a claim they attribute to his success.

The passage concludes by noting the potential fate of this report, similar to Nemtsov's earlier works, which, despite exposing corruption and the true cost of the 2014 Sochi Olympics, failed to incite significant public protests against Putin.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered deceased in the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on a Monday. The post-mortem revealed that the 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn, Rotherham, died due to head injuries. Subsequently, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones expressed frustration over the UK government's handling of Brexit, specifically regarding the Article 50 letter triggering the UK's exit from the EU. Jones stated he was not consulted before the letter's publication and was not involved in its drafting, deeming this "unacceptable" and indicative of a lack of respect towards devolved administrations. He emphasized this point during an Assembly meeting, highlighting the UK government's aim to develop a negotiating framework for the entire UK.

Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered Jones' criticism, noting Prime Minister May's frequent visits to Wales and the ongoing discussions about the letter's contents over several months. Cairns asserted that the UK government must act in the best interests of the whole UK.

In her letter to Donald Tusk, May mentioned consulting fully with devolved administrations about the return of powers, expecting a significant increase in decision-making power for Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. However, the specific powers in question remain unclear, causing concern for Jones who fears there might not be sufficient funding to accompany these powers post-2020.

The passage also hints at differing views within Whitehall about the distribution of EU funds in Wales, potentially influencing the decision to devolve certain powers to Westminster. A white paper on the Great Repeal Bill was expected to provide more details, but as of the time of the passage, the identity of the powers to be devolved remained a mystery.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on a Friday night. The attack also targeted PSNI officers, causing Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin to express his dismay. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page confirmed that the police were on duty when they were attacked. The police have appealed to the community, particularly parents, to monitor their children's activities and whereabouts to prevent such incidents.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was dismissed last year due to employee complaints and allegations of financial misconduct. The company's board stated they do not anticipate his return. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claims many of these accusations are false and accuses the company of privacy invasion and extortion. Court documents reveal illicit emails from Charney to female employees and racially offensive remarks. These allegations are in response to Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The company asserts that Charney repeatedly violated its sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies. The board argues that due to these violations, it would be challenging for any company to hire Charney in a leadership role, citing potential risks to the company and shareholders. Recently, a restraining order was issued against Charney, prohibiting him from making negative press statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The British women's basketball team will face Greece in a rematch at the Copper Box, London, which will be broadcast live on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app. The teams previously met in Patras, Greece, where Greece won 92-64. Three key Greek players will be absent, providing Britain an opportunity for revenge. Guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about the home game, noting it's crucial for preparation for the EuroBasket 2017. This game is Britain's sole home match before their EuroBasket participation, which begins in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the Greece game, the team will head to a four-nation tournament in Poland for further preparation. The match is scheduled from 17:30 to 19:30 BST.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the launch of the first iPhone in 2007. Despite initial skepticism and the phone not being readily available for media, the author secured an opportunity to handle the device for a news segment. The author drew a comparison between the iPhone's potential impact and that of the Model T Ford, suggesting both were transformative technologies. The iPhone indeed proved revolutionary, making powerful computers accessible to over two billion people and significantly altering various industries, particularly photography. Before the iPhone, while there were phones with cameras and devices for internet browsing, they were underutilized due to lack of user-friendly interfaces. Steve Jobs' innovation lay in creating an appealing user interface, making smartphones more than just communication tools. The author, initially dismissive of the hype, now views the iPhone launch as a pivotal moment in technological history, marking the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Seven cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have died from antifreeze poisoning in the past month. The most recent victim was seven-month-old Meereen, who died on Monday after showing symptoms of shivering, foaming from the mouth, and attempting to vomit. Her owner, Adria Pearce, is devastated. Three other cats died in the last seven days, and another two weeks ago. The RSPCA confirmed all cats ingested the toxic substance, though the cause remains unclear - whether accidental or deliberate. RSPCA inspector Andy Bostock is urging residents to safely store pesticides and chemicals, especially antifreeze, which is commonly used during this time of year in cars. He emphasizes the importance of ensuring there are no leaks or spills, and that any spills are cleaned up properly.

The passage discusses the apparent contradiction in Greece's current situation. Despite the Syriza government, led by Alexis Tsipras, preparing to implement further austerity measures as demanded by creditors, there are no significant protests in Athens. Instead, Greek resorts are experiencing a boom, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year, an increase from 21 million. This surge in tourism might be due to Greece appearing safer than resorts near areas controlled by the Islamic State.

The passage questions why Greeks aren't protesting against already-announced austerity measures like VAT increases and pension cuts, and anticipated reductions in farm subsidies, privatizations, and market liberalization. It suggests that the calm could be due to the impending revelation of the extent of Tsipras' concessions to secure €86bn in new credit from the eurozone and possibly the IMF in the third bailout.

Tsipras' shift from opposing such measures to now embracing them is attributed to Greece's near-death experience in July, which led to bank closures and economic collapse, making him adopt a 'TINA' (There Is No Alternative) stance. Despite failing to end fiscal austerity and saddling Greece with monetary austerity due to bank closures, Tsipras remains popular.

The passage concludes that while there's relief in the eurozone over Syriza's submission, the new bailout's success hinges on Tsipras offering hope for better times. Many believe that for genuine recovery, creditors, especially Berlin, need to ease Greece's unsustainable debt burden by a third to a half, showing debt forgiveness in the face of Athens' capitulation.

Ross Kemp, who previously portrayed Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, is set to make a brief return to the show. This return is to coincide with the emotional storyline involving his on-screen mother, Peggy Mitchell, played by Dame Barbara Windsor. Peggy, who made a surprise reappearance in Albert Square after leaving in 2010, revealed that her cancer had returned. She will die from the disease in upcoming spring episodes. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for what will be her final scenes. Kemp expressed his enthusiasm about returning to EastEnders, describing the upcoming episodes as "classic". The executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, emphasized the significance of this storyline, highlighting it as an opportunity to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden (who plays Phil Mitchell) at their best, as the Mitchell brothers confront the loss of their mother. Grant Mitchell, one of EastEnders' most iconic characters, is returning home to say goodbye to Peggy and reconnect with his brother and past loves.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was found guilty of stalking and murdering Alice Ruggles, a 24-year-old, in October of the previous year. Dhillon had become obsessed with Ruggles, leading to a pattern of stalking behavior. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, recounted the moment they learned of their daughter's death, instantly recognizing Dhillon as the perpetrator. Prior to the tragedy, Alice had called her mother, who tried to reassure her that the situation was under control. However, Alice's friend Emma had warned her mother that Dhillon intended to kill Alice. Despite this, Hills dismissed Emma's concerns, leading to feelings of guilt. The parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, emphasizing their desire for their daughter to be remembered by her vibrant personality and positive traits. Dhillon, 26, was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison for his crimes.

French energy firm EDF has approved the £18bn Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project in Somerset, with contracts set to be signed. However, the UK government, led by Business Secretary Greg Clark, has announced it will "consider carefully" before committing to the project, causing EDF's CEO Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a trip to Hinkley Point. The project, one-third of which is funded by Chinese investors, has faced criticism over potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign ownership concerns. 

The government's decision to review the project again, just hours after EDF's approval, has surprised EDF executives and strained Anglo-French relations post-Brexit. Critics, including environmentalists and industry leaders, argue that delays could lead to energy supply issues and higher costs, potentially hindering the UK's climate commitments. 

Hinkley Point C, expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, was described by EDF as a significant asset for both French and British industries, promising job creation and sectoral boosts. Yet, EDF's financial capacity has been questioned, with the company recently raising €4bn through new shares to fund the project. 

A board member resigned over the project's financial risks, and EDF's finance director had previously left due to concerns about Hinkley Point's potential to harm EDF. Environmental groups like Greenpeace oppose the project, advocating instead for investments in renewable energy sources like offshore wind. The project's timeline includes key milestones such as the government proposing nuclear power in 2006, construction approval in 2013, a 2013 agreement on electricity pricing, and a 2015 investment deal with China.

The passage discusses changes to the divorce application form in England and Wales, which now explicitly asks for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery. Family lawyers, including Margaret Heathcote from Resolution and Georgina Hamblin from Vardags, express concerns that this addition may increase conflict and complexity in divorce proceedings. They argue that naming the third party is often unnecessary and can lead to that person becoming involved in the court case, potentially causing delays and additional costs. Despite the form's guidance stating it's "not normally necessary" to name the third party, lawyers fear that many will feel compelled to do so due to the prominent question. If named, the third party receives court documents and can respond, which judges generally discourage. The passage also notes that adultery was the reason for 12,148 of the 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales in 2015. The Ministry of Justice maintains that there's no obligation to name the third party, emphasizing it's merely a relevant part of the divorce proceedings.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental policy and commercial forestry in Wales. Britain, as the world's third largest wood importer, relies heavily on timber, with Wales contributing significantly to this industry, estimated at over £450m annually. Conifer forests, prevalent for half a century, have aided the timber sector's growth. However, since 2001, around 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost and require replanting, according to Confor, the forestry industry promoter. 

The conflict arises as ministers prioritize native, broadleaf species and improved public access, while conservationists argue that commercial forests negatively impact wildlife. Some forests are also challenging to reach and harvest, causing friction with local communities during timber transportation. 

The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development, referencing the Glastir scheme that incentivizes farmers and landowners to plant woodland. The Woodlands for Wales strategy envisions high-quality woodlands that enhance the landscape, offer social benefits, support industries, and improve the environment.

Martin Bishop from Confor, representing 200 Welsh businesses, criticizes the current system as overly bureaucratic for new woodland creation. Despite 90 hectares being planted last year, 20,000 hectares annually are needed to meet long-term targets. Bishop highlights a substantial market demand for timber, with saw millers expressing interest in increasing production if sufficient timber supply was available.

A boy sustained severe injuries in an incident in Coatbridge, specifically on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School. The event occurred around 16:40, prompting emergency services to respond. The boy was subsequently transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported to be critical.

The passage details the presentation of Ushakov medals to British veterans of the Arctic Convoys by Russian Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko. These convoys, which took place during World War II, involved British vessels traveling from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union. The journey was fraught with danger, including constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe weather conditions, and ice floes. By May 1945, 104 merchant and 16 military vessels had been lost, resulting in thousands of Allied seamen's deaths.

Initially, the Foreign Office blocked Russia from honoring these veterans due to rules against foreign medals being awarded more than five years after the event. However, following a campaign, the British Government created the Arctic Star in 2012 to recognize these veterans. The Russian Embassy, under Minister-Councillor Alexander Kramarenko, persisted in awarding the Ushakov medal, viewing it as a symbol of gratitude for the critical role the convoys played in the Allied victory on the Eastern Front.

The Foreign Office eventually made an exception to its rule, allowing the presentation of the Ushakov medal. President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London in June 2013. One of the recipients, 91-year-old Charles Lewis, expressed his honor and delight, though he modestly rejected the 'hero' label, viewing the convoys as part of their duty during the war effort. The passage underscores the perilous nature of these missions, often referred to by Winston Churchill as "the worst journey in the world".

The HM Inspectorate of Probation report highlighted significant delays and inefficiencies in implementing unpaid work sentences, often referred to as "community payback". In one instance, an offender had completed only 16 hours of unpaid work in 17 months post-sentencing. The report, based on an analysis of 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders, outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. 

Key issues identified include difficulties in organizing offenders, many of whom lead chaotic lives with substance abuse issues, to attend their unpaid work on time. The report also noted that sanctions for non-attendance often result in prison, while lack of sanctions renders the sentence unenforceable. 

Despite these challenges, the report acknowledged instances of high-quality work and offenders who viewed their sentences positively, gaining skills and expressing determination to avoid future offenses. 

The report's recommendations emphasized reducing the frequency of offenders being turned away when they report on time and tailoring unpaid work objectives to individual offenders' circumstances. The chief inspector, Paul Wilson, criticized the current approach for viewing unpaid work primarily as punishment, calling it a "wasted opportunity". 

The Ministry of Justice responded by accepting all recommendations and committing to implement them, aiming for more effective rehabilitation, including ensuring offenders attend their unpaid work and face consequences if they don't. The report also mentioned a historical note about the government's order for 10,000 orange bibs for offenders under the "community payback" scheme, intended to symbolize a tough alternative to imprisonment.

The article criticizes comedian Russell Brand for being labeled a "hypocrite" by The Sun newspaper. The criticism stems from Brand's advocacy for economic and political revolution to aid the poor, despite living in a luxurious London home. Viewers of his vlog, The Trews, are aware of his spacious residence. When confronted by a Channel 4 News reporter about his living situation during a protest against gentrification in east London, Brand reacted negatively, calling the journalist a "snide" and walking away. The Sun's accusation isn't new; Brand has been called a hypocrite before. 

In response, Brand acknowledges his wealth and fame, admitting he needs to change and advocates for personal and systemic change. He argues that wealth sharing is part of this change, but without broader systemic reform, it would be ineffective. Brand accepts his past mistakes but emphasizes the urgent need to address economic inequality and ecological crises. He criticizes those who dismiss his concerns about inequality, suggesting they don't want the issue on the agenda due to its severity. Brand believes his hypocrisy is a problem that can be gradually resolved. He hasn't responded to Newsbeat's inquiry about potential legal action against The Sun and Rupert Murdoch, but has been tweeting about the accusations using the hashtag #TheSunLogic.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the human genome mapping process by turning it into a competitive race, despite facing criticism from the scientific community. Born in 1946, Venter initially showed little academic promise, focusing on surfing in his youth. His experiences during the Vietnam War, where he served as a naval orderly, instilled in him a sense of urgency and a desire to become a doctor. 

Venter excelled in research during his medical training, and by the 1980s, he was working at the National Institute of Health (NIH), recognizing the significance of gene decoding. However, he found the process slow and cumbersome. In 1987, he introduced automated decoding machines to accelerate the process. His breakthrough came when he shifted focus from the entire DNA blueprint to the RNA molecules that cells naturally use, enabling rapid gene sequencing.

This approach, while groundbreaking, drew criticism, notably from James Watson, who dismissed Venter's work. The criticism and lack of public funding led Venter to establish The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992 and later Celera Genomics in 1998, aiming to decode the human genetic code in three years, compared to the public project's 10-year plan. Both efforts published their results in 2001.

Post-human genome project, Venter founded the J. Craig Venter Institute to create synthetic life. In 2008, they announced Synthia, a synthetic organism, in the journal Science. Simultaneously, Venter has been conducting oceanic expeditions, collecting microbial life forms to enhance understanding of genetic evolution and function.

Venter's synthetic life creation, while controversial, is seen by him as potentially sparking a new industrial revolution, with synthetic microbes aiding in environmental conservation by reducing dependence on oil and capturing carbon dioxide. Despite his unconventional methods and wealth, Venter's contributions have significantly advanced the field of genomics.

A survey of approximately 1,000 parents in England, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, revealed that 80% of children who consume school lunches have tried foods at school they hadn't tried at home. Half of these parents reported their children asking to replicate these school-tried foods at home. The most favored vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergines, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. 

The research was prompted by a Mumsnet survey suggesting some parents opt for packed lunches due to their children's perceived fussiness. Rob Rees, chairman of the School Food Trust, noted that school meals can assist parents in encouraging their children to try new foods and diversify their diets. Carrie Longton, co-founder of Mumsnet, highlighted that while healthy eating is a parental goal, home mealtimes can be challenging. However, she observed that school environments, with their peer influence and varied, healthier options, can positively impact children's eating habits. 

Currently, about 40% of primary school children and slightly more in secondary schools in England partake in school lunches. This figure is slightly lower than in Scotland, where around 46% of schoolchildren eat school meals. The online survey was conducted between February 26 and March 5 among parents with children aged 4-17.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016, moved to Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid. The transfer included a buy-back clause for Real Madrid, priced at up to 30 million euros (£23 million). Morata, previously a target for Arsenal and Chelsea, has netted three times for Spain in Euro 2016. 

During his two-year stint at Juventus, Morata scored 27 goals and helped the team win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He also featured in consecutive Champions League finals, substituting in Real Madrid's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. 

Morata began his career at Real Madrid, making his debut at age 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club. He stands at 6 feet 3 inches tall and has been a key player in both La Liga and Serie A.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, rejoined Nottingham Forest from Celtic in August 2013 for £2.5 million. His second stint at the City Ground lasted until his release in May, during which he made 51 appearances. Prior to his time at Celtic, Wilson had already spent four seasons with Forest. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County in the past. The passage concludes by directing readers to a dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

Tesco, the world's third-largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to a private equity firm, Yucaipa, based in Los Angeles. This move is part of Tesco's strategy to exit the US market in an "orderly and efficient" manner. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transition to the new business. The deal involves Tesco loaning the new entity around £80m. Fresh & Easy, operating 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since its launch in 2007. Tesco will incur a £150m cost for this disposal, but part of this is the aforementioned loan, which could potentially be recovered. The remaining 50 stores will be shut down. Yucaipa, led by billionaire investor Ron Burkle, specializes in supermarket and restaurant businesses. Tesco reported its first annual profit decline in 20 years in April of the current year. If Yucaipa succeeds in making Fresh & Easy profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake in the business.

The passage discusses an individual's journey in martial arts. Initially, this person faced racial abuse but managed to overcome it. At one point, they contemplated representing France in martial arts competitions. Currently, their focus is on aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The text also suggests a special guide for those interested in learning about martial arts.

The passage discusses a significant reduction in glacial coverage in the French Alps over the past four decades. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields covering Mont Blanc and surrounding mountains spanned approximately 375 sq km. By the late 2000s, this area had shrunk to around 275 sq km, marking an average loss of about 26% over 40 years. This research, presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting, was conducted by Marie Gardent from the University of Savoie and her team. They assessed about 600 glaciers in various massifs, including Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye, Grande Rousse Arves, and Mont Blanc.

The study utilized map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual verification to correct potential errors from automatic delineation methods, especially due to debris cover or deep shadows. The only previous French Alps glacial inventory, from four decades ago, also reported around 375 sq km of ice coverage. By 1985-86, this had decreased to about 340 sq km, showing an initial retreat. However, the pace of retreat accelerated thereafter.

The glacial retreat is not uniform across the French Alps. The southern sectors, particularly the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs, have experienced the most significant losses. In Belledonne, glaciers have almost vanished, and in Ecrins, the retreat is over three times faster than in the Mont Blanc Massif. This disparity is attributed to lower elevations and different climatic conditions in the south, including less precipitation and cloud cover compared to the north.

The northern region, home to the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has seen less dramatic changes. Despite a slight decrease from 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to just over 30 sq km currently, its retreat is less severe than in the south. Similar glacial mass loss trends have been reported in the Swiss Alps, underscoring a broader regional issue.

Scotland's women's national football team, led by forward Kim Little, is on the brink of securing a spot in the 2017 World Cup after winning all five qualifiers.
