They host Iceland, currently ranked 20th in the world, at Falkirk Stadium. A win would significantly increase their chances of qualification, as both teams are unbeaten. Iceland, being top seeds, pose a tough challenge, but Scotland sees this as an opportunity. The match and the return game in Reykjavik on September 20 are crucial in determining the group's top position. 

Kim Little, who recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the importance of fan support and the team's emotional investment in reaching the finals for the first time. Twelve players in the 20-strong squad play abroad, primarily in England, Sweden, and the US, which Little believes enhances the national team's competitiveness. She highlights the benefits of training with top-tier players in Germany, noting the high level of competition and the positive influence on her game. Little also acknowledges the progress in Scottish women's football, though she stresses the value of international experience brought by players playing in different leagues.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger behind Wings Over Scotland, was arrested in the west of England on a Friday following a harassment complaint from a woman in her 30s from south London. The alleged harassment spanned over two years, primarily involving tweets from Campbell's account. Campbell, who was released on bail pending further inquiries in mid-September, denied the allegations, stating the tweets were not threatening and accused the media of creating "innuendo" to fuel speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating the online harassment case. Campbell also noted on his blog that he would be posting less frequently due to reasons unrelated to the arrest.

Peta is advocating for a modern, animal-friendly mascot to replace Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman. They propose a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice". The Jolly Fisherman, originally commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908 for 12 guineas, has long been associated with the Lincolnshire resort, symbolizing "Skegness is so bracing". However, Peta's representative, Dawn Carr, argues that the Jolly Fisherman symbolizes animal cruelty, referencing practices like fish being impaled and overcrowded in nets. Carr suggests the new mascot would rebrand Skegness as a progressive holiday destination, not celebrating the mutilation or killing of sea animals. 

Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, welcomes all suggestions but believes there wouldn't be significant support for replacing Jolly. He asserts that Jolly is perceived as a happy, friendly figure who effectively promotes Skegness. Macey maintains that while animal cruelty isn't something Skegness wants to be associated with, Jolly doesn't convey that image. He concludes that unless there's a compelling reason, they won't change the beloved mascot.

Scotland dominated their rugby match against Georgia, scoring six tries in total. Georgia took an early lead through Vasil Lobzhanidze's try, but Scotland quickly responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson and Hogg added more tries in the second half. Despite Georgia's second try from another Lobzhanidze score following a powerful scrum, Scotland maintained their lead, with Hogg scoring his second try late in the game. The match was marked by Scotland's superior possession and territory control, though they faced some disjointed play due to a wet and cold condition. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's pragmatic approach and improvement in managing games. The final score was 38-22 in favor of Scotland.

Widnes secured a 38-26 victory over Castleford in a closely contested match. Widnes took a 14-6 lead into halftime, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge. Paddy Flynn, on loan from Widnes to Castleford, scored twice in the second half for Castleford, but Widnes responded with further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor, extending their lead to 38-12. Despite Castleford scoring three tries in quick succession - from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick - Widnes managed to hold on to their lead. The match saw Castleford's defense struggle, particularly after conceding a try to Mellor following a short kick-off. This victory moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth, one point ahead of Widnes. Notably, Castleford's Larne Patrick, who recently signed a three-year deal from Huddersfield, and Paddy Flynn, on loan from Widnes, were key players in the match.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from the US detention facility in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after a review panel determined he was no longer a "continuing significant threat". Al-Odah had been held since 2002, following his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, claims he denies. He had previously challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Upon his release, he boarded a Kuwaiti government plane, expressing no bitterness or anger, only joy at returning home. However, he is expected to spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. The Kuwaiti government had been advocating for the release of all Kuwaiti detainees from Guantanamo. Al-Odah asserted that he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release, the first since May, reduces the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility, established in January 2002 following the 9/11 attacks, has been a subject of President Barack Obama's repeated promises to close.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, was marked with significant services in London. Thousands gathered for the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 participating in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey, where Anzac Day commemorations began in 1916 with King George V's attendance. 

The event is crucial for expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, honoring their countrymen's sacrifices in all wars. Australian High Commissioner to the UK, Alexander Downer, addressed the crowd at the dawn service, reflecting on the Gallipoli landings' courage and heroism. 

The parade at the Cenotaph involved veterans, service and ex-service personnel, and their families. The ceremony included prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign, a bloody eight-month operation in Turkey, was an allied attempt to expel the Ottoman Empire from the war.

Steven Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has rejoined St Mirren for a second spell, potentially making his debut against Alloa in the Championship on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals for Dundee and has been training rigorously to maintain his fitness, despite only featuring as a substitute this term. Clarkson, who has two caps for Scotland and over 390 senior club appearances, including stints at Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, expressed his readiness and eagerness to contribute to the team. St Mirren currently stands eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of Alloa. Clarkson emphasized the importance of each game, aiming to boost team confidence and push for a higher table position.

Turkey firm Bernard Matthews was acquired by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Initial concerns arose about the new owner potentially disregarding the existing workers' pension scheme. However, Unite regional officer Steve Harley reported positive discussions, receiving assurances that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, would be upheld. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current members are part of an alternative scheme unaffected by the takeover. Boparan's Private Office confirmed the continuation of the existing pension arrangements. Harley met with Boparan representatives at Bernard Matthews' headquarters, where it was emphasized that the new owner aims to restore the company to its former profitability. This would be accomplished through increased investment, cost reductions, and utilizing current capacity to process chicken, not just turkeys.

The council, led by Dave Stewart, held a scrutiny meeting to address issues with a newly launched ferry service between Cowes. The ferry, which began operations on May 14, has faced multiple problems including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. These problems have negatively impacted local businesses, with shopkeeper Angie Booth expressing concern about potential business closure due to lost trade. 

In response, the council has decided to offer free crossings until July 2 to gather feedback and has ordered an auditors' review of the project. Transport councillor Ian Ward acknowledged the teething problems, attributing some issues to electrical glitches that have since been fixed and seamanship concerns that have been resolved with ramp extensions. Ward also left open the possibility of compensating affected local businesses, though no definitive decision has been made.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has issued a report on the potential risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. Despite fishing contributing only half a percent to the UK's GDP and employing just 12,000 fishers, the Lords emphasize that the industry should not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. 

The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP), which allows equal access to fishing grounds for all member states, has been criticized by the British fishing industry. This policy was a significant factor in mobilizing the industry to vote for Brexit, with many hoping for regained control over UK waters and a resurgence as a leading fish exporter, similar to Norway.

However, the report highlights that most commercial fish stocks are in shared waters with EU coastal states. The UK exports a large portion of its fish, primarily to the EU, and imports a significant amount, often from EU countries. Therefore, continued market access is crucial, but it may come at a cost. The UK might need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in its waters in exchange for maintaining access to the EU market with zero tariffs.

The report also suggests that elements of the CFP, such as scientifically-based quotas, should be retained post-Brexit. The UK will still be obligated to cooperate with neighboring states on fisheries management. A potential concern is the fragmentation of the current CFP framework, which treats the UK as a single entity, leading to four separate fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland.

Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about Brexit. They believe it will bring opportunities for fairer catch shares and improved, sustainable management. Recent EU agreements on new fishing quotas, which increased allowable catches for plaice, haddock, and prawns, are seen as a positive sign for the future of British fishing outside the EU.

The government, in response, has stated its intention to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade in the single market while using Brexit as an opportunity to review and improve fisheries management for fair access, sustainable stocks, and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old teacher, admitted to taking or allowing the creation of child sexual abuse images between 2004 and 2014. He was initially sentenced at Dumfries Sheriff Court, where it was revealed that most images depicted young boys partially dressed in erotic poses, though no sexual activity was evident. Geaney was placed on the sex offenders register and subjected to a community payback order, including a special sex offender program. 

A General Teaching Council Scotland (GTC Scotland) hearing later found his actions "fundamentally incompatible" with teaching, concluding that his conduct condoned and participated in an industry that violates and abuses children. The panel deemed his behavior a pattern over a lengthy period, indicating a strong likelihood of recurrence. Consequently, Geaney was deemed unfit to teach and removed from the teaching profession's register. He was prohibited from reapplying for re-registration for two years, and was not present at the GTC Scotland hearing.

On 2 March, a fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's site in Duncan Street led to significant disruptions in train services and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) subsequently suspended the company from accepting waste. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws, the firm faced enforcement action due to concerns raised by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) about potential impacts on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. GMFRS had visited the site nine times in the past year. The EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective from 8 August, unless an appeal is filed. The cause of the fire remains unknown. The company, managed by Asset and Land Group, has been ordered to remove all waste from the site.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated to the BBC that Syria is making efforts to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timeline, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Two shipments were sent to the coast, with the second one reportedly intercepted by fire from "terrorist groups." Mekdad emphasized the ongoing war in Syria and the need for this context to be considered.

He criticized U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, which activist groups claim have killed hundreds, including children. Mekdad denied these allegations, asserting that Syria is defending against "terrorist attacks" and has never bombarded civilian areas.

Regarding the central prison in Aleppo, state media denied rebel control, while opposition groups reported that the Islamic Front coalition, including al-Nusra Front, had seized the facility, freeing hundreds of detainees. The prison is reported to hold at least 3,000 detainees under poor conditions.

Syria possesses approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% (30 tonnes) reportedly exported so far, according to the U.S. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel. The U.N. and OPCW have noted the operation's slow progress due to security concerns. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its agreements and obligations under the OPCW and UN Security Council. Russia, a key ally, has set a deadline of 1 March for the completion of the transfer of chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship.

England secured a dominant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared their first innings at 589-8 and their second at 173-1, resulting in their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was pivotal, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. Root was named man of the match. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, describing it as one of the best Test-match innings he's seen. 

Pakistan's performance was lackluster, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. They were bowled out for 234 in their second innings. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott and commentator Michael Vaughan highlighted England's superior batting, bowling, and discipline, predicting another England win in the upcoming third Test at Edgbaston. 

Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, acknowledged the team's low confidence and poor shot selection, expressing disappointment and hope for improvement before the next match. Only Misbah and Asad Shafiq have scored over 50 in the first two Tests for Pakistan.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is initiating a review to assess the quality of life and care for older individuals in residential care. She plans to gather evidence from pensioners, their families, and caregivers to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both positive and negative experiences, focusing on aspects such as physical and mental health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Her team will also consult with care providers and social care staff. The review's goal is to ensure that those responsible for these services understand the realities of residential care and the necessary changes to improve the quality of life for older residents.

Mario Kreft, the chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's objectives but expresses disappointment that no care home provider, manager, or owner is included in the main advisory panel. He believes this omission misses an opportunity for collaborative partnership and full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Aberdeen midfielder, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, where he led the team to win the Scottish Third Division title and secure promotion in 2011, their first national trophy. Arbroath were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's CEO, Duncan Fraser, stated that Sheerin was chosen after a thorough process by head coach Derek McInnes. Despite Arbroath's chairman, John Christison, wishing to retain Sheerin's services, he expressed understanding and support for Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has a history of playing for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Swansea City will be managed by assistant manager Paul Williams and coach Alan Curtis for their upcoming match against Bournemouth, following the sacking of Bob Bradley. The club aims to appoint a new permanent manager swiftly, with ex-Derby boss Paul Clement being their top choice. Curtis, a former player who witnessed Swansea's rise through the divisions, believes the team has lost its identity and "Swansea Way" since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent management changes. Despite this, Curtis is confident that the current squad, aware of the club's history and the importance of staying in the Premier League, is capable of avoiding relegation. He emphasizes the club's significant progress from near-bankruptcy a decade ago to Premier League promotion in 2011, and reminds new signings of this journey through a documentary titled "Jack to a King". The club acknowledges the difficulty of bouncing back from relegation, citing the strengthening Championship and the challenges faced by other clubs like Norwich and Burnley.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the human genome mapping process, turning it into a competitive race. Despite his controversial methods and self-promotion, his efforts significantly accelerated the process. Born in 1946, Venter initially pursued surfing and avoided academic excellence. His experiences during the Vietnam War, however, inspired him to become a doctor and instilled a sense of urgency in his work.

In the 1980s, Venter began working at the National Institute of Health, focusing on gene decoding. He introduced automation to speed up the process, then shifted focus to messenger RNA to rapidly generate gene sequences. This approach, though criticized by some, including James Watson, led to significant breakthroughs.

In 1992, Venter left NIH to establish The Institute for Genomic Research due to funding issues and criticism. He then founded Celera Genomics in 1998, aiming to decode the human genetic code in three years, compared to the public project's 10-year plan. Both efforts published their results in 2001, with Venter's approach, though controversial, yielding substantial financial rewards.

Post-2001, Venter formed the J. Craig Venter Institute, focusing on creating synthetic life forms. In 2007, they announced Synthia, a synthetic organism, in the journal Science. Simultaneously, Venter led the 'Ocean Sampling Day' project, collecting marine microbial genetic data to enhance understanding of gene and protein evolution.

Venter's synthetic life creation, while controversial, is seen by him as potentially revolutionary, with the capacity to reduce dependence on oil and mitigate environmental damage by capturing carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust warns that many English apprenticeships are of low quality and too short, contrasting with Germany's robust vocational education system. The study, conducted by Boston Consulting Group, indicates that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts in England are at level three, equivalent to A-levels. This is in stark contrast to Germany, where over half of employers offer apprenticeships and 570,000 new ones are for young people, many equivalent to A-levels. 

The report highlights that only 61,000 new apprenticeships in England are for young people, and 58% of apprenticeships since 2010 have been below level three. Seventy-five percent have been aimed at those over 25, many of whom are already employed. England's vocational system has 18,000 qualifications, compared to Germany's 330. 

Sir Peter Lampl, chairman of the Sutton Trust, criticizes the current system as a "complicated patchwork" that offers qualifications of little worth, confusing employers and society. He advocates for a radical expansion of apprenticeships, proposing up to 300,000 new starts annually, with a majority at level three for at least three years. 

The Department for Education counters that they are reforming apprenticeships to enhance standards, noting that over a million people have become apprentices since 2010, providing a good career start. They plan to publish further reforms to improve apprenticeship quality. The Association of Colleges supports the need for higher-quality level three apprenticeships but cautions that some level two apprenticeships, like those in construction, are respected by industry and should be preserved. They also emphasize the necessity of high-quality facilities and expert teaching staff for vocational courses, along with improved career guidance.

Sarah Storey, a 37-year-old British Paralympian, won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory marks her 22nd Paralympic medal, including 11 golds, 8 silvers, and 3 bronzes across six Paralympics. She is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian. Storey, who also won four golds at the 2012 London Games, has amassed 21 world titles in both cycling and swimming. She began her Paralympic journey in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Games, before transitioning to cycling in 2005. Storey is aiming for further success, including a potential 17th title in Saturday's road race and at the 2016 Rio Paralympics.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to unpaid debts, primarily to football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle, current squad members, and clubs from which they loaned players. The club's financial troubles began after their relegation from the Football League in May 2012, worsened by declining attendance. Despite fundraising efforts by fans and a £1 offer from the Hereford United Supporters' Trust, the club failed to secure the necessary funds. The new owner, Tommy Agombar, was unable to meet the extended payment deadlines. Chester, who were relegated in 2010 and reformed as Chester FC, have taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier. The last team expelled from the Conference before Hereford was Chester City in 2010. Hereford's players, who fought to keep the club in the Conference Premier in the final game of the season, are now left without success due to the board's decision.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player now aged 30, has represented England 61 times since his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played for three minutes during Euro 2016. Milner expressed support for Sam Allardyce and the team, wishing them success in the future. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 appearances since 2004. Milner's international career includes scoring his only goal for England in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his Cambridge home after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with a public memorial service planned for a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and led it for three decades, touring across six continents. The AAM produced over 200 CDs, notably the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. His renowned recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, hailed as one of the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine.

Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and began his career as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields. He was also a founding member of the Early Music Consort of London. He served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a tutor at Harvard University, honorary professor at the University of Cambridge, and a professor at Cornell University.

Colleagues remember Hogwood for his generosity, being a great ambassador for historically informed music, and his role in nurturing many leading musicians. His legacy is highlighted by the impact he had on the music industry and his commitment to authentic period performance. Tributes emphasize his intellectual prowess, genial personality, and dedication to letting the music speak for itself.

A family from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being withheld, is struggling to secure a place for their son in a special school. The boy, who has special needs, was removed from mainstream education in June due to his inability to cope. His parents applied for a spot in a special school in September, but were informed that all such schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were fully occupied, with no estimated time for availability. The boy's mother expressed his distress over isolation, as he doesn't understand why his siblings can attend school while he cannot. Recently, the family was informed that an additional classroom assistant has been hired at a local special school, potentially allowing their son to start there soon. However, the mother is concerned this situation may recur for other families, given the oversubscribed state of special needs schools. The Education Authority, while unable to comment on individual cases due to privacy concerns, stated they are reviewing the need for special school places across Northern Ireland to ensure availability from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting a takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons, with plans to transform Rodney Parade into a rugby-focused venue. Newport County, currently using the stadium under a lease until 2023, insists on honoring their contract. The takeover will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on May 9th. Newport County, who gained promotion to the Football League in 2013, is protected by their current lease agreement, as confirmed by Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. Newport County, currently two points ahead of the League Two relegation zone, could secure survival this weekend. Relegation would be a significant setback, according to County's chief executive, Neil Foxall, not only for the fans but also for the city of Newport.

The passage recounts the harrowing experiences of an individual during Sierra Leone's civil war (1991-2002) and his subsequent work during the Ebola crisis in 2014. The speaker was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels at age 15, enduring brutal training and witnessing extreme violence. He managed to escape, lived as an outcast in Freetown, and was eventually taken in by a preacher named Richard Cole, who founded the Lifeline Nehemiah project. This project aimed to provide hope and education to former child soldiers, encouraging them to rebuild the nation.

When the Ebola virus hit Sierra Leone in 2014, the speaker and his community viewed it as a common enemy. They transformed their clinic to handle suspected Ebola cases, focusing on three key activities: education, providing food and supplies, and setting up an Ebola treatment unit. They educated over 10,000 people about Ebola, distributed aid to 11,000 individuals, and collaborated with other agencies to establish a treatment unit.

Despite initial fear and resistance from the community, their persistent efforts saved many lives. The speaker recounts a particularly distressing incident involving a pregnant woman with suspected Ebola, which motivated them to establish an Ebola treatment clinic. The speaker now views his life as transformed, expressing regret for past actions but optimism for the future. He emphasizes the importance of investing in young people to bring about positive change, not just in Sierra Leone, but globally. The passage also provides statistics on the Ebola outbreak, noting that Sierra Leone had 3,955 probable, confirmed, and suspected deaths.

A public fundraising campaign successfully averted the auction of approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The collection, which was intended to be sold to help pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, reached its fundraising target within a month. The Art Fund led the campaign, and the collection will ultimately be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. 

The Wedgwood Museum inherited the pension bill from Waterford Wedgwood plc, which collapsed in 2009. In 2011, a high court judge ruled that the museum's collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. Alison Wedgwood, a descendant of Josiah Wedgwood, emphasized the collection's importance to Staffordshire, warning that it could have been "sold and scattered around the globe" without the fundraising success. 

Tristram Hunt MP, involved in the campaign, praised the outcome, stating that the items in the Wedgwood collection represent a significant part of Britain's cultural development and national identity. The administrator, Bob Young, expressed satisfaction with the resolution, attributing the success to the "spirit of goodwill and determination" shown during negotiations.

Billericay Town Football Club is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points away from a play-off spot. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. A potential deal is being negotiated where 30-year-old Joe Wright, known for his appearance on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011, would acquire a 20% stake in the club and become a director. Wright has a history of playing non-league football for various clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in March. The specifics of the Wright deal are still under discussion.

Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Nathan Delfouneso's chip was turned into the goal by Jamille Matt. Colchester equalized in the 24th minute through Kurtis Guthrie from a corner. Despite several close calls, neither team managed to take the lead before halftime. Blackpool missed a golden opportunity to win in the 75th minute when Tom Aldred headed wide from close range. Colchester played with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with Blackpool's goal scored by Matt and Colchester's by Guthrie.

The Fawley power station, located on the western side of Southampton Water, is set to be transformed into a "merchant city" development. The 300-acre site, which was commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation, will feature a petal-shaped glass structure as its centerpiece. This £1bn project, proposed by developers Fawley Waterside, includes a marina, residential spaces, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The 1971-commissioned, 198-metre-high oil-fired power station chimney, capable of powering one million homes, will remain standing, making it the tallest such attraction south of London's Shard. The developers aim to leverage the existing chimney, likening it to structures like Brighton's i360 and Portsmouth's Spinnaker Tower, with minimal additional investment. An application for outline planning permission is expected later in the year, with potential construction starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old British cyclist Jacob Latham secured a bronze medal in the men's omnium event. He overtook Adrian Teklinski of Poland (gold) and Lucass Liss of Germany (silver) in the final sprint. In the men's team pursuit, Britain was beaten by Italy for the bronze. 

Joe Truman, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, was eliminated in the semi-finals. The women's team pursuit squad, comprising Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, failed to advance past the heats and finished 5th. Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker, who joined the team, remained optimistic about their future prospects.

Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman and six-time Olympic gold medallist Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's strategic race, noting his effective sprint and smart positioning. 

Earlier, Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, expressing disappointment but emphasizing her focus on the upcoming Tokyo Olympics. She is set to compete in the 500m time-trial and keirin.

Ross Kemp, who previously portrayed Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and 2005-2006, is set to make a brief return to the show. This return is to coincide with the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who was revealed to have cancer upon her surprise return to Albert Square. Peggy, Phil Mitchell's mother, will die from the disease in emotional scenes scheduled for spring. Kemp's return aims to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for a final time. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins emphasized the significance of this reunion, expecting it to highlight the acting prowess of Kemp and Steve McFadden, who plays Phil Mitchell. Grant Mitchell, one of EastEnders' most memorable characters, was involved in numerous family dramas, including an affair with his brother's wife and his brother marrying his ex-wife.

Sadio Mane scored twice rapidly (138 seconds) as Liverpool defeated Tottenham Hotspur at Anfield. Spurs, currently in second place, struggled, with manager Pochettino acknowledging their lack of desire and inability to handle pressure, which he believes could jeopardize their Premier League challenge. Spurs have only won twice away from home since September 24, including losses at Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City. In their last 17 matches against top-six teams away from home, they've won just once. Former Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized their defensive performance, noting their usual back three was replaced with a back four, contributing to their poor showing. Murphy emphasized the need for Spurs to improve their away form and mindset quickly. Chelsea, currently leading the Premier League, could extend their lead if they win against Burnley on Sunday.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent gubernatorial elections, winning 19 out of 28 declared governor posts. This marks the PDP's most substantial defeat since the end of military rule in 1999, following their loss in the presidential election last month where Muhammadu Buhari of the APC defeated incumbent President Goodluck Jonathan.

The APC's triumph was evident in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, traditionally PDP strongholds. However, the PDP managed to retain control of Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships mostly in the south-east. Taraba's result is still pending, and Imo's election was declared inconclusive due to a larger number of spoiled ballots than the margin of victory.

Notably, the APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari given potential disruptions from militant groups. The PDP's loss is attributed to voter fatigue after 16 years in power, allegations of corruption, and perceived failure to address the Boko Haram insurgency.

The elections, while marred by 66 reported violent incidents - mostly in southern states - were generally more peaceful than previous elections, indicating a maturing democracy in Nigeria. The PDP is now expected to undergo a period of introspection and rebuilding under new leadership.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), set to occur in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, is introducing an augmented reality (AR) app feature. This app will enable visitors to access online content by scanning items like signs and posters on the festival site. The content includes videos, band interviews, and more, viewable on mobile devices. Notable acts performing this year are The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlighted that this AR experience aims to enhance visitor enjoyment and allow global interaction, providing a taste of the festival's atmosphere remotely. The app will also facilitate real-time updates, ticket purchases, and access to festival information.

Birmingham's Park View and Nansen Primary schools, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. The Park View Educational Trust may be removed from managing these schools. Similarly, Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned of potential funding loss unless issues are addressed.

A head teacher at one of these schools, who wished to remain anonymous, reported that parents attempted to undermine her authority and spoke to Ofsted inspectors about her during an inspection. She felt isolated and considered quitting, but found solidarity when the Trojan Horse scandal broke.

Ofsted published 21 reports on schools allegedly targeted in a hardline Muslim takeover, with five, including Park View and Oldknow, rated inadequate. The reports highlighted issues like inadequate student safety measures, unvetted external speakers with extremist views, and segregation of boys and girls.

Education Minister Lord Nash criticized the Park View Trust for failing to promote the spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils and for not eliminating discrimination or advancing equality. He set a July 4 deadline for the trust to address these issues or face termination of funding.

Oldknow Academy Trust received a similar letter outlining necessary actions, including ending discrimination against non-Muslims and ensuring a balanced curriculum. Both trusts were invited to respond before July 4.

Parents at these schools have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and loaded questions, and have invited Education Secretary Michael Gove for an open meeting to discuss the evidence supporting the findings.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court claims that eye specialist Honey Rose, 35, acted criminally due to her conduct falling significantly below the expected standards. Ms. Rose, from Newham, east London, is accused of failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation. This alleged negligence led to a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, increasing pressure in his skull and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution asserts that Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had performed her duties competently. The severity of the risk involved, according to Jonathan Rees QC, made her conduct so poor that it was criminal. Ms. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man from Guthrie, near Forfar, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse with a man he arranged meetings with, from September 2013 to September 2014. The meetings were set up by Weatherhogg and filmed without the woman's consent. He was also convicted of sending a sexually explicit video to the victim's sister on Christmas Day, 2014, and of threatening or abusive behavior towards the victim's family. Weatherhogg denied all charges but was found guilty following a trial at Dundee Sheriff Court. The case was escalated to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its severity. The judge, Lady Wolffe, emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting societal disapproval of such conduct. Weatherhogg, a first offender, was deemed to pose a moderate risk of sexual re-offending. He was placed on the sex offenders register and is awaiting sentencing, which has been described as a "dramatic shock" to him.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson contributing 56 runs, Gary Wilson adding 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield scoring 39. Afghanistan chased the total comfortably, reaching 171-4 with two overs to spare, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai opened with a 51-run stand. Afghanistan's Amir Hamza was the most successful bowler, taking 2-23. Ireland's Porterfield acknowledged they fell short of a potential 180, and also noted issues with their bowling execution. The loss of Boyd Rankin due to a back injury was a further setback for Ireland, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs starting on 15 March. The teams will meet again in the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, have denied any wrongdoing in the Neymar transfer, stating they made a supplementary tax payment of €13.55 million to cover potential interpretations of the contract. The club initially paid £48.6 million to Santos for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34 million. Including wages, agents' fees, and other costs, the total expenditure on Neymar is estimated at £106.8 million. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid allegations of misappropriating funds related to the transfer, which he denies. A Spanish judge has ruled there's enough evidence to continue investigating the club. Despite the payment, it's unclear if the case will be closed. Neymar, who has scored 7 goals in 18 La Liga matches and 3 in 7 Champions League games this season, remains a key player for Barcelona.

British detectives have concluded their investigation into the murders of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, on Koh Tao beach, Thailand, on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both aged 21, are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery. They allegedly confessed to the killings, though Thai police deny reports that they have retracted these confessions. The suspects could face the death penalty if convicted. 

Post-mortem examinations revealed that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge succumbed to head wounds. DNA evidence found on Witheridge reportedly matches samples from the suspects. The UK Foreign Office expressed concerns to Thailand about the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects. 

A team of UK detectives, who flew to Thailand last month, have now completed their work and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The investigation was facilitated following a meeting between UK Prime Minister David Cameron and Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha, who initially rejected foreign assistance.

Scotland's women's national football team, led by forward Kim Little, is on the brink of securing a spot in the 2017 World Cup after winning all five qualifiers. They host Iceland, currently unbeaten with four wins, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would significantly increase their chances of topping the group, with the return match in Reykjavik on September 20 likely to determine the group leader. 

Evans, a 24-year-old Bayern Munich forward, emphasizes the team's determination to avoid another play-off heartbreak, having lost twice previously for Euro 2013 and the recent World Cup qualifiers. The top six group runners-up qualify automatically, placing Scotland in a strong position.

Iceland, ranked 20th globally, is considered a tough opponent, but Evans believes Scotland has a good chance to win. She highlights the importance of fan support, noting that a big crowd at Falkirk could make a significant difference.

Evans, one of 12 players in the squad who play abroad, recently won the women's Bundesliga in her first season with Bayern Munich. She describes the experience as "mind-blowing," sharing stories of celebrating with the men's team and rubbing shoulders with football stars like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben.

The benefits of having players in top global leagues, particularly in Germany, are evident. Evans notes that the competitive Bundesliga enhances her skills and those of her teammates, contributing to the national team's growth. She acknowledges the improving Scottish league but stresses that international experience adds a different dimension to the national team's play.

The passage discusses a security vulnerability in Apple's iCloud service that led to the theft of intimate celebrity photos. This breach was facilitated by third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which allowed hackers to bypass Apple's existing two-step verification process. This software could download complete iCloud backups even if users had enabled two-step verification, as it didn't apply to iCloud's backup service.

In response, Apple has introduced a new security measure. This involves an additional step for accessing iCloud from a new device: after entering the username and password, users must input a four-digit code sent to a trusted phone number or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. Without this code, users cannot access their iCloud or make purchases from iTunes, iBooks, or the App Store. They can, however, use a 14-character recovery key to regain access if their trusted device is lost or stolen.

ElmcomSoft's owner acknowledged that his software was likely used in the hacks but noted that Apple's changes effectively block his technique. However, he raised concerns about the recovery key's usability and potential for theft. 

Security experts like Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey suggest that Apple should make two-factor authentication the default setting, not an opt-in choice, to enhance security. They argue that single-step verification, such as passwords, are too vulnerable. Apple has responded by stating its intention to more aggressively encourage users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, emphasizing the need for increased user awareness about security measures.

During the 2014 European election campaign, UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives at £2,980,815, Lib Dems at £1,580,575, and Labour at £1,027,339. UKIP secured the highest number of votes (4,376,635) at a cost of 68p per vote, while Labour came second with 26p per vote. The Conservatives spent 79p per vote and the Lib Dems, who lost 11 out of 12 MEPs, spent £1.45 per vote. The Green Party, which came fourth, spent £534,249, equating to 43p per vote for their 1,255,573 votes. The six highest-spending parties collectively spent £9,347,087, with all except Labour spending more than in the 2009 election.

Centre-back Anderson, a 27-year-old former player for Aldershot, Exeter, and Italian clubs, has mutually agreed to terminate his contract with Barrow to join their National League rivals. He might play against his previous club, Barrow, on 28 February. Additionally, Torquay United (Gulls) have signed 21-year-old striker Keating, recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has experience with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, pending international clearance. Torquay's manager, Kevin Nicholson, described Anderson as a leader with the right stature and voice, despite his limited game time for his age. Keating, on the other hand, is seen as young and raw but highly motivated. Torquay currently sits four points above the relegation zone, having won just one of their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died shortly after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He narrowly beat Thistlecrack in a closely contested race. Veterinary staff treated him, and the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) confirmed he suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. Tony Welsh, acting chief veterinary officer for the BHA, stated that such incidents are rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues across all disciplines of sport horses.

Many Clouds had a history of post-race ataxia, causing him to overheat and wobble, but he had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms on the day of his death. He was a successful horse, having won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. His trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime".

Despite the rarity of this incident, the BHA is committed to further understanding the causes and exploring preventive measures. There were questions about a potential link between Many Clouds' history of overheating and his death, but the report concluded that his cause of death was a rare haemorrhage.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, was visibly emotional during the farewell speeches of veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. McNeil, who has served since the parliament's establishment in 1999, warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system, emphasizing the need for accountability and scrutiny. He stressed that failing to meet this challenge would have consequences. 

Salmond, who served as First Minister from 2007 to 2014, used his valedictory address to reiterate his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse". He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill, but criticized it for not fulfilling unionist pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond joked about the timing of his speech, noting it wouldn't be overshadowed by the UK budget, and wished all candidates luck in the upcoming election, albeit with varying degrees of enthusiasm. He concluded by expressing that serving in the parliament is the greatest honor and task in public life.

Marwick also thanked Salmond for his distinguished service, both as an MSP and as First Minister. Other MSPs, including former Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie, are also stepping down. Goldie humorously mentioned she would miss dealing with Finance Secretary John Swinney, particularly his "huge outbursts of faux indignation". The election is set for 5 May.

Emma Watson, known for her role as Hermione Granger in the Harry Potter series, has been cast as Belle in Disney's live-action adaptation of "Beauty and the Beast". Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father, while Dan Stevens, famous from "Downton Abbey", will portray the Beast. Luke Evans will take on the role of the antagonist Gaston. Josh Gad, recognized for his voice role as Olaf in Disney's "Frozen", will play Gaston's companion LeFou. Emma Thompson will play Mrs. Potts, the teapot, originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film. Bill Condon, director of "Dreamgirls" and the final two "Twilight" films, is set to direct the movie. Filming is scheduled to commence in May at Shepperton Studios, with the film's release date set for 17 March 2017 in US cinemas.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to disclose its plans regarding potential charges in connection with the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans tragically lost their lives in this incident. Last year, new inquests concluded that the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence files of 23 suspects were handed over to the CPS to determine if charges should be pursued. These include 15 suspects related to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 related to an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police post-disaster. The meeting, led by Sue Hemming, head of the CPS's special crime and counter-terrorism division, will take place in Warrington. Margaret Aspinall, whose 18-year-old son died, expressed hope that this meeting marks the end of their long journey, emphasizing the families' desire for accountability rather than retribution. Despite anticipating a day of mixed emotions, the families remain determined and resolute in their pursuit of justice.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, raising concerns among nearby residents. A former inmate described the prison as notorious for the prevalence of mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the issue, stating that staff work hard to prevent contraband, but more needs to be done. They mentioned that the Justice Secretary has instructed them to explore methods to equip prisons with better tools to combat this problem. A local resident reported witnessing such incidents four times in two weeks, though she doesn't feel personally threatened. The former inmate also claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, a claim the Ministry of Justice denied, citing lack of evidence. The MoJ did confirm that new laws have been enacted, imposing up to two years' jail time for those caught smuggling packages into prisons.

Brian Wright, 55, from Kempston, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for allegedly causing serious injury to Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, outside Bedford Road Lower School in December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not realize the traffic lights were red. He admits to striking Mrs. Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, who had been a lollipop lady for 20 years, suffered serious head injuries and is now receiving residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse, stating he has been haunted by the incident and its impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The prosecution alleges that Wright's VW Golf failed to stop at a red light, hitting Mrs. Blackburn as she was guiding a woman and her six-year-old daughter across the road. The trial is ongoing, with the court hearing that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been directly in Wright's line of vision.

Jemma Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner, has announced she won't be part of the Scotland team for the upcoming Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. Her exams are scheduled for May, clashing with the April Games. Muir expressed her disappointment, stating she cherishes representing Scotland but prioritizes her degree. She remains optimistic about future Olympic opportunities, suggesting she might have two to three more in her. Muir also mentioned the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target, despite her intense study schedule. At the recent World Athletics Championships in London, Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds in the 5,000m, finishing 6th. She expressed satisfaction with her performance, noting the tough competition and her potential for future races.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, disappeared on his way home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search has commenced in a three-acre woodland area beside the R112 and River Liffey in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, six detectives initiated a comprehensive review of Deely's disappearance. Enhanced CCTV footage revealed Deely conversing with a man in black outside his workplace, Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, likely to retrieve an umbrella. The same man was later seen on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road. Despite releasing the footage and appealing for the man's identity, he remains unidentified, and authorities have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th due to injury-related absences, secured a victory over Swiss player Stanislas Wawrinka (31) in a four-set match (3-6, 6-3, 7-6(7-2), 6-3). This win marks Del Potro's first Grand Slam appearance since the 2014 Australian Open, following three wrist surgeries. Despite initial struggles, Del Potro rallied, particularly in the second and third sets. He expressed immense joy and gratitude, noting the support from the crowd and his fellow players. 

In other matches, Australia's Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, overcame a two-set deficit to defeat Germany's Dustin Brown (85th rank) in a grueling five-set match (6-7(7-3), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4). Spanish player Feliciano Lopez (22nd seed) advanced after a comeback against Italy's Fabio Fognini (36th seed), winning 3-6, 6-7(7-3), 6-3, 6-3, 6-3. 

Other notable wins include 10th seed Tomas Berdych defeating Germany's Benjamin Becker (6-4, 6-1, 6-2) and 12th seed Jo-Wilfried Tsonga triumphing over Argentina's Juan Monaco (6-1, 6-4, 6-3). These results set the stage for upcoming matches, with potential clashes between Murray, Kyrgios, and other players in the later rounds.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced significant hurdles regarding their participation in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was initially at risk of being disqualified from the 2017 tournament after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) over a controversial penalty awarded during their quarter-final against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 tournament. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) strongly contested the referee's decision, but insisted they did not accuse Caf or the referee of corruption. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia managed to resolve their differences and were allowed to participate in the 2017 tournament.

Meanwhile, Morocco was banned from the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw due to their refusal to host the 2015 tournament, citing Ebola fears. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) later overturned this ban, reducing a fine imposed on Morocco's FA from $1m to $50,000. Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa expressed optimism about the future of African football and Morocco's involvement.

Both countries have now been included in the tournament. Tunisia will compete in Group A, facing Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti. Morocco has been placed in Group F, alongside Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. If Tunisia qualifies for the 2017 finals, it will mark their thirteenth consecutive appearance, setting a new record.

McLaren, a historically successful Formula 1 team with 182 race wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a significant slump. The team's decline began in 2013 due to issues in chassis design, despite having a superior engine. The current problems lie with the Honda power-unit, marking a stark contrast to their past glory years, particularly the 1980s when they dominated with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988.

The team's last constructors' title was in 1999, and they were unjustly stripped of the 2007 constructors' title due to possessing Ferrari's technical information illegally. More controversy ensued in 2009 with 'lie-gate', leading to the dismissal of sporting director Dave Ryan.

McLaren's fortunes have fluctuated over the years, with periods of dominance followed by decline. Ron Dennis, who has been instrumental in the team's rise and fall, returned to take control after the disastrous 2013 season. Despite the current struggles, Dennis remains optimistic, asserting that McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again. This optimism is partly fueled by Fernando Alonso's return in 2015, driven by his belief in the renewed Honda partnership as his best chance for a third world title.

Currently, McLaren's progress is largely based on belief, as they strive to regain their former glory and fulfill the expectations tied to one of F1's most prestigious team names.

On 6 October 2014, at 06:00 BST, paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven following a sudden death. Police arrived shortly after, discovering patrons still present and till receipts indicating alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. As a result, the judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both from Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill faced two counts and Thomas faced one. The court heard that Dungiven's licensing laws were not strictly followed, with the premises operating well into the morning. The judge noted O'Neill's "appalling record" and expressed concern over his inability to impose a custodial sentence. O'Neill was fined £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for the most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry, who entered the game four 3-pointers shy of his previous record of 272, hit six before halftime and eight overall, including his final one to surpass his record. He also added nine assists. Klay Thompson contributed 26 points, helping the Warriors recover from a 13-point deficit. 

In other news, the Chicago Bulls, led by Pau Gasol's 16 points and 15 rebounds, overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78. The Bulls went on a remarkable 39-8 run after halftime, outscoring the Heat 57-27 in the second half. Derrick Rose, in his comeback from injury, scored 12 points. The Heat, on the other hand, were hampered by Dwyane Wade's poor shooting (4 for 20) and Hassan Whiteside's 19 points and 16 rebounds.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen surprised Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic at Melwood training ground. The players were led to believe they were meeting a competition winner for a free-kick masterclass. However, van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills on YouTube, showcased his abilities, impressing the Liverpool quartet. His strikes, particularly one that sailed into the top corner, left the stand-in goalkeeper helpless. Balotelli also demonstrated his free-kick prowess. Van Velzen, a Dutch free-kick specialist, became a YouTube sensation by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits. He revealed he enjoyed pretending to be less skilled at free-kicks to see the players' reactions. As a final surprise, he unveiled Balotelli's famous slogan, referencing the Italian's infamous t-shirt from Manchester City's 6-1 win over Manchester United in 2011. Van Velzen described the experience as "amazing," fulfilling every fan's dream of playing football with their idols.

Angelina Jolie, who carries the BRCA1 gene mutation, serves as an example for women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the same gene. A Canadian study indicates that removing ovaries, a procedure known as oophorectomy, can significantly reduce the risk of death from breast cancer. For BRCA1 carriers, this risk drops by 62% on average, and for those who have the surgery within two years of diagnosis, it decreases by 73%. The study, published in JAMA Oncology, also found a 65% reduction in all-cause mortality. The protective effect of oophorectomy is immediate and lasts for 15 years. The benefits are particularly pronounced for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. Women with a significant family history of breast cancer, especially those who inherit the faulty BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, have a 50-80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer. Genetic testing is available for those likely to carry these mutations, which are more common in the Ashkenazi Jewish population. Jolie, who had both breasts removed (double mastectomy) two years prior to the oophorectomy, reported feeling feminine and grounded in her decision, emphasizing the importance of personal choice in healthcare.

On Easter Sunday, around 10 AM, a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina. The incident occurred on property owned by Norfolk-Southern as the train, number 80 (The Carolinian), was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, though a passenger who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for approximately two hours and 45 minutes before resuming its journey. 

A local man, James Thompson, reported that the couple might have been homeless and lived in a nearby camp. Thompson described them as having a grocery cart and often asking for small favors. He emphasized the importance of kindness towards those in need. Durham, where the incident took place, is about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next stop, and the usual travel time from Charlotte to New York City is around 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, spent 27 years working as an undercover operative for the DEA in exchange for U.S. citizenship. Toro fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss, fearing for his life. He provided crucial information about his former associates, aiding in the prosecution of key figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro's work was instrumental in numerous undercover stings worldwide, making him one of the DEA's most valuable assets. Despite his contributions, he was not granted citizenship as promised. Health issues forced his retirement, leaving him technically living in the U.S. illegally. The DEA and government bureaucracy have refused to assist him, causing him severe distress. Toro fears deportation, stating he would be killed within hours upon return to Colombia. His former colleague recently provided $5,000 for an operation, but he remains in legal limbo, unable to secure a green card, passport, or collect social security benefits. Toro is prepared to go into hiding if necessary, emphasizing he has atoned for his past mistakes and only seeks the citizenship he was promised.

The U.S. Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal practices involving the new '.sucks' domain. Vox Populi began accepting registrations for '.sucks' domains on March 30, targeting trademark holders and celebrities before making them available to the public. Notable figures like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have had their names registered under '.sucks', with Vox Populi recommending an annual fee of $2,499 for these domains. 

Celebrities like Kevin Spacey have reportedly paid to have these domains removed, while others, like Taylor Swift, have had to defensively spend to remove their names from similar 'adult' domains in the past. Vox Populi CEO John Berard claims the domain is intended to facilitate interaction between companies and their critics, asserting their business is within ICANN rules and the law.

However, an advisory panel comprising major companies and industry groups, including Microsoft, Verizon, and eBay, has labeled this as a'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory'. They've requested ICANN to halt the rollout of '.sucks', arguing the threat of average consumers creating such sites later is part of Vox Populi's coercive strategy. 

In response, ICANN has sent a letter to the U.S. Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal. If found in breach of contract, ICANN could seek to alter Vox Populi's behavior or implement other remedies.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby's body was discovered in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. The body was found by teenagers in June 1988 and initially, the case remained unsolved. In 2014, during a periodical review, the baby's body was exhumed and a DNA sample led police to the mother. She admitted to concealing her pregnancy, delivering the baby stillborn, and placing the body in the pond. Initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide, the charge was dropped when she explained the circumstances. The woman has been released on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service decides whether to charge her for failing to register the birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied in the churchyard of St Peter's Church, named Peter after the church, with a new headstone funded by a support group for parents of stillborn children. Police confirmed no foul play was involved, and the case was solved using advanced DNA techniques. The original burial, marked by a simple wooden cross, had been unnamed until the recent reburial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, 56, a former soldier, was ordered by the High Court to compensate Kristopher Hicks, now 27, for severe brain injuries sustained when he jumped from a moving taxi. The incident occurred five years ago when Hicks, then 23, was returning home from a night out in Bath, Somerset, with his girlfriend. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued driving for nearly a mile, prompting Hicks to jump from the vehicle, which was traveling over 20mph. This resulted in Hicks suffering severe brain injuries, developing epilepsy, and requiring round-the-clock care from his mother.

The court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, making him entitled to damages. The exact amount of compensation, expected to be around 50% of the family's request (potentially hundreds of thousands of pounds), is yet to be determined. Hicks' lawyer, James Davies, stated that the incident left Hicks with devastating brain injuries, post-traumatic epilepsy, headaches, fatigue, social and behavioral problems, and a loss of taste and smell. He is unable to work and relies on 24-hour care from his mother. The judge, Mr. Justice Edis, acknowledged the "stark and unattractive choice" Hicks faced and concluded with a 50% reduction in damages, also awarding Hicks £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties were given permission to appeal, with a further hearing to decide the final compensation amount.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms produced reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted approximately 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, but it moved northeast, bypassing the city but posing risks to other communities. CNN's Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are particularly dangerous. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas, specifically near Aetna, about 125 miles southwest of Wichita.

The storms also affected other states; a potential tornado touchdown was reported in Potosi, Missouri, around 70 miles from St. Louis. Potosi experienced wind damage, flooding, and hail, with one Instagram user posting a photo of a fallen tree and aerial footage showing damaged roofs and flooded streets. Nearby Leadington saw unusual dark clouds, while Farmington reported baseball-sized hail.

More severe storms are forecast for the midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes, according to the National Weather Service.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive victory and a title shot. Rockhold plans to dominate by being aggressive, cutting off Machida's typical evasive movements, and forcing him into a ground fight where Machida is less effective. Rockhold respects Machida's martial arts skills but is confident in his own diverse skill set, including his speed and hip movement. He's been training intensely, even running marathons daily.

Machida, coming off a win against C.B. Dollaway, is also confident and believes he can exploit Rockhold's weaknesses. He's well-prepared after an eight-week training camp with notable fighters like Glover Teixeira. Both fighters acknowledge each other's skills but are determined to impose their own styles and secure a potential title shot. The winner of this fight believes they should be next in line for a title bout, with the current contender being the victor between Jacare Souza and Yoel Romero.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar plane, performed a gear-up landing at Aero Acrees residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane touched down without deploying its landing gear, causing it to skid along the runway on its belly, damaging its propellers. The video maker, observing from the flight line, noted the unusual descent and the subsequent impact, describing the sound of propellers hitting the ground as unforgettable. Upon realizing his mistake, the 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, re-engaged the engines and managed to take off again, despite the high angle of attack and damaged propellers. Georgaklis, an experienced pilot with nearly 50 years of flying, successfully flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely, accompanied by his dog, Buddy. The incident, likely caused by human error, is under investigation by the FAA. Gear-up landings are typically due to pilot forgetfulness or mechanical failure.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's underperformance this season but pledged to support him until the end of the campaign. Sportsmail reported that City would consider offers for Toure, who has two years left on his £220,000-a-week contract, as they aim to revamp their aging squad following a disappointing season. Despite criticism, Toure is determined not to leave and Pellegrini maintains that the 31-year-old remains a crucial player. City, who have gathered only 18 points from their last 39 league games, face West Ham, with a loss potentially allowing Liverpool to narrow the Premier League gap. The team will also be without captain Vincent Kompany, who may miss the remainder of the season due to a muscle injury. Goalkeeper Joe Hart acknowledged the players' responsibility for their poor form but affirmed Pellegrini's continued support within the dressing room. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce warned left-back Aaron Cresswell, who is attracting interest from City and Chelsea, against following English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who struggled for playing time at the Etihad Stadium.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia member known as the 'Godfather of Uxbridge', will be allowed to stay in the UK after his sentence was effectively dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years, was sentenced to seven years in Italy in 1999 for his role in the Cosa Nostra. He was arrested in 2013 following a lengthy extradition battle, but his case expired in October 2014 due to Italian law, which extinguishes a sentence once more than double the time has passed. Despite his conviction still standing, the European Arrest Warrant is to be withdrawn. His solicitor, Karen Todner, expects the Italian government to discharge Rancadore from proceedings. The case will still be reviewed by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore, who lived under the name Marc Skinner, was arrested after being tried in absentia for his role as a'man of honor', taking bribes from builders in Palermo. The extradition process has been criticized for its length and cost, with legal experts expressing disappointment over the waste of time and resources.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of the three 7-2 co-favourites for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other co-favourites are Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre, who will be ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. AP McCoy, who will retire after this race, will ride Mr. Mole. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The final lineup for McCoy's last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. Notably, it was after winning the Newbury race on Mr. Mole in February that McCoy announced his retirement. The other competitors in the Celebration Chase include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered in 1975, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time, 40 years after the crime. Marcia, who was 12, was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Her body was discovered 33 days after her disappearance in a cluttered, windowless garage, covered by a shower curtain and a child's wading pool. Initially, Ritter's then-husband advised against seeing the body and photos, but last year, she requested to view them from Mickey Miller, the lead investigator. 

The photos revealed Marcia's body was severely disfigured, with a swollen face, black mouth, vomit, pulled-out hair, and blood on her scalp. Despite the horrific condition, parts of her body still looked like Marcia. This experience prompted Ritter to express a desire for revenge, stating she would kill Barrett if she had a gun. 

Barrett, 68, was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison. He was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence linked him to the crime. The case was Nashville's most notorious unsolved murder for 33 years until Barrett's arrest. Earlier, in 1979, a neighbor was charged but later released due to lack of evidence. Barrett had been in prison on sex charges between 1974 and 2002, with a brief period when Marcia disappeared.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, believes it's "unthinkable" that he won't eventually win the Masters, completing the career grand slam. This would make him the sixth player to achieve all four major titles, following in the footsteps of Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, and Tiger Woods. McIlroy, 25, views his final-round collapse at the 2011 Masters as the most crucial day of his career, as it led to significant learning and growth.
