Despite this, he bounced back strongly, winning his first major title, the US Open, two months later.

McIlroy has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, finishing 8th in 2011. He's optimistic about his chances at Augusta, considering it a course where he can excel and potentially win multiple times. He emphasizes the importance of focusing on his game rather than the hype surrounding the tournament. McIlroy's resilience was evident in his ability to overcome personal distractions, such as the cancellation of his wedding and a costly legal dispute, to achieve extraordinary success in 2014. He hopes to use the golf course as his sanctuary once again at the Masters, where he can block out external pressures and concentrate on his performance.

This week, several trending stories dominated online discussions. In the New York area, following heavy rainfall, four rainbows were spotted in the early morning sky, captured by Amanda Curtis, CEO of a fashion company. In rural China, a new trend of hiring exotic dancers for funerals is being curbed as part of a broader crackdown on vice activities. Robert Downey Jr. became agitated during an interview in the UK where he was questioned about his private life. A new beauty trend, lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner, emerged, involving sucking on a jar to achieve fuller lips, which gained traction under the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge. 

102-year-old Alice Barker, with the help of filmmakers, recreated scenes from her past, effectively 'going back in time'. A prom proposal involving a bomb reference was rejected by a school, sparking accusations of racism from the proposer. Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in the upcoming 'Beauty and the Beast' film, generating significant social media interest. The trailer for 'Black Mass' featuring Johnny Depp, who is nearly unrecognizable, also made waves. A creative pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" and a military dad photobombing his son during a graduation were other notable trends.

272 children were hospitalized in England over the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), according to data from the official Health and Social Care Information Centre. However, experts suggest the actual number of affected children could be significantly higher. Research by the World Health Organization indicates that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb, equating to about 7,500 annually. 

Elizabeth Mitchell of the National Organization for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome emphasizes that children with FAS do not improve and that the issue is vastly underdiagnosed. A case study is provided of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, who was adopted and diagnosed with FAS at age five. Niamh requires assistance with daily tasks and will never live independently due to her condition. 

Alcohol consumption during pregnancy can also lead to other medical issues such as liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Current UK government advice recommends that pregnant women should not drink more than two units, up to twice a week. However, Mitchell advocates for stricter guidelines, suggesting women should abstain from alcohol entirely during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as 'Boomerang Boy' or 'Homing Pigeon Boy' due to his tendency to return home after committing crimes, was jailed for six years for attempting to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham. On March 15 at 8 PM, McKerry, masked and wielding an axe, burst into the store and demanded cash from assistant Andrea Brighty. The store owner, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry, causing shelves and produce to fall. McKerry's wife, Sam Dhillon, assisted by hitting him with a baseball bat twice, helping to disarm him. The struggle revealed McKerry's face to the security cameras. Blood was seen coming from McKerry's nose as police arrived and arrested him. McKerry had a history of crime, starting shoplifting at age 12 and accumulating 80 arrests by 15, with convictions for aggravated vehicle-taking, sending indecent letters, and burglary. He earned his nicknames in the 1990s due to being arrested 80 times in 1995 and 45 times in 1998. He once stole 22 charity boxes while dressed as a woman, earning him the local moniker 'one-man crime wave'.

Four Royal Navy sailors - Joshua Finbow, 23, Craig Stoner, 24, Simon Radford, 31, and Darren Smalley, 35 - have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a Canadian naval barracks in Nova Scotia. The alleged assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors returned from an ice hockey game. The victim, in her early 20s, had accompanied a friend to a party hosted by local Canadian servicemen. 

The sailors appeared in a Dartmouth court, where they were given bail conditions that include living on the Stadacona naval base in Halifax, surrendering their passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy. Bail was set at over £2,000 each. They are forbidden to contact the victim or six witnesses, cannot leave Nova Scotia, and must not resign from the navy without court permission. 

The charges against them are sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, both punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing, and forensic tests may lead to additional charges. The British High Commission is assisting Canadian authorities with the investigation. The sailors are due back in court on May 27.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, faces the challenge of raising her four-year-old son, RJ, who suffers from Netherton's syndrome, an extremely rare skin disease. Only 70 people worldwide have this condition, which causes RJ's skin to appear red, scaly, and inflamed, often leading to misinterpretation as child abuse. Recently, while shopping, Valerie was confronted by armed police, called by a concerned stranger who mistook RJ's condition for abuse. Valerie regularly applies creams to prevent RJ's skin from drying out and cracking, and she and her husband, Reginald, have to manage his painful symptoms. 

RJ was diagnosed with Netherton's syndrome shortly after birth when Valerie noticed a spreading red rash. The condition, a more extreme form of ichthyosis, affects one in 200,000 births in the UK. It causes skin to lose heat, water, and protein rapidly, often leading to hospitalization in incubators. As RJ grows, his skin may remain red, scaly, and sensitive, with potential issues like infections and allergies. Despite the lack of a cure, symptoms often improve over time.

Valerie and Reginald have encountered significant societal challenges, including being denied entry to play centers and facing harsh comments from other parents. RJ has also been bullied, with adults often making cruel taunts. Despite these hardships, Valerie remains committed to her son's well-being and advocacy for better understanding of Netherton's syndrome. She emphasizes RJ's cheerful and bubbly nature, hoping that as he grows, his condition will become more widely recognized and accepted.

The controversial 'Are You Beach Body Ready?' adverts by protein world, featuring a toned model named Renee Somerfield, are being removed from London Underground stations. The three-week advertising period has ended, and Transport for London (TFL) confirmed the posters' removal, though they noted only one official complaint was received. Over 50,000 people signed a Change.org petition demanding the ads' removal, citing concerns about promoting unhealthy body images and objectifying women. Several posters were also defaced by angry bloggers.

The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has received more than 200 complaints. TV presenter Susanna Reid described the campaign as "anxiety-inducing" during an interview with Protein World's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley. Staveley defended the campaign, stating it aims to inspire health and fitness, not to offend. He also revealed the company has faced threats, including a bomb threat, reported to the police.

Despite the backlash, Protein World has actively engaged on social media, defending their campaign and responding sharply to critics. Sales of protein powder, a key product of the brand, have been growing in the UK, from £73m in 2007 to £170m in 2012, and are projected to reach £358m by 2017. Some public figures, like Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick, have supported the brand, arguing against body-shaming and in favor of personal responsibility for health and fitness.

Rail firms, including First Great Western (FGW), are facing criticism for planned fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite both major party leaders pledging to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron, whose constituency includes the route between London and the Cotswolds, has requested FGW to "urgently review" its decision to nearly double some fares. Specifically, off-peak return fares from Charlbury to London, passing through his Witney constituency, will rise from £33.30 to £62.40 on May 17, an 87% increase. 

The fare hikes have angered Cameron's constituents, prompting his personal intervention. FGW justifies the increase by stating it aims to align the North Cotswolds route with its other services. However, they are also offering cheaper advanced single tickets as an alternative. 

Other significant hikes include a 24.5% increase in the cost of an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool with Virgin Trains, and a 22% rise in an anytime first-class day return from Manchester to Stoke. Virgin Trains defended its hikes, stating they primarily affect 'Virgin trains-only fares' which are at least 20% cheaper than competitors' tickets, with their overall fare increase at 1.65%, below the industry average. 

The passage also mentions that train companies can increase 'unregulated' fares, which account for about half of their revenue, three times a year. These fares often include off-peak leisure and advance-purchase tickets.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his newlywed wife Elaine, 54, were attacked in their home in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple was sitting in their front room on April 18, around 11:20 PM, writing thank-you cards for their wedding gifts when thugs began pelting their front window with stones. After one brick shattered the glass, John went to confront the attackers, opening the door. He was then struck in his left eye by another brick, causing an open wound to his forehead and severe injury to his eye. Despite emergency surgery, doctors couldn't save his eyesight, leaving him blind in one eye. 

John, a retired HGV driver and former soldier who served in the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers during the Irish Troubles, expressed shock and fear, stating he no longer feels safe in his own home. The attack occurred just three weeks after their wedding. Elaine, who works for the Alzheimer's Society charity, said they have no idea why they were targeted. 

Police have launched an investigation but found no apparent motive, suggesting it could be a case of "yobs messing around." Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam emphasized the seriousness of the act, noting the permanent disability and loss of sight John now faces. He urged anyone with information to come forward. The couple plans to move to Southport due to their fear of the neighborhood.

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension following his successful return from a significant injury. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in the death of his father, Keith. He underwent an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour in Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's Elite Performance Director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing the club's delight in his return. The new contract is intended to boost Poynton's confidence, as he has shown promising form since his return to training and in Abu Dhabi.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 children annually in the UK. The cancer was found in his kidney, lungs, bones, and neck. To cope with his treatment, Harley created and decorated a Ninja Turtle-themed protective mask for his radiotherapy sessions. His bravery and story gained widespread attention, including a gesture from children's TV channel Nickelodeon, who sent him a box of Ninja Turtle presents for Christmas.

Harley underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at the Christie Clinic in Manchester. Despite complications from the stem cell transplant, he battled through and returned home for his fifth birthday. Recently, doctors informed Harley's parents, Oliver and Stacey Renshaw, that he is cancer-free. Harley will continue to undergo regular check-ups to ensure his ongoing health.

His family is overjoyed, with his father expressing his pride and excitement for the future. Harley's bravery has also earned him a Cancer Research UK Little Star Award and made him the face of the charity's Kids and Teens campaign, aiming to fund research into child cancers. Neuroblastoma typically affects children under five and is the second most common solid tumor in childhood, often spreading to other parts of the body. Symptoms can include pain, loss of appetite, and swelling, depending on the tumor's location. Treatment varies based on the child's age, tumor size, and spread, often involving surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Tim Sherwood, former Aston Villa manager, advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his club career over his international future. Grealish, a 19-year-old midfielder, has been impressing with his performances for Aston Villa, notably in their FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool. This has caught the attention of both the Republic of Ireland and England, who are vying for his international allegiance. Sherwood believes Grealish should focus on solidifying his place in the Villa first team, emphasizing that his current success is a result of his efforts at the club. Sherwood, drawing from his own experience with Nabil Bentaleb, suggests that Grealish should make his decision based on his personal feelings. Grealish's father, Kevin, echoes this sentiment, urging his son to maintain his club form. The young player is expected to make his international choice by the end of the season, but for now, both his club and family advocate for him to concentrate on Aston Villa.

The passage discusses the significant and often surprising disparities in landing fees for private jets at various airports worldwide. This trend is particularly relevant for the wealthy, as private jet travel is a growing industry worth billions in the US and Europe. In 2013, 2.5 million private flights were recorded in the US and 705,000 in Europe. 

The text highlights that these fees reveal some unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the affluent, such as Salzburg, Austria, and Darwin, Australia. For instance, Salzburg Airport charges £2,530 for landing a 767-400 jet. 

The passage also notes that certain weekends, especially during major sporting events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, see a surge in private jet usage and higher landing fees. For example, a round-trip from New York to Glendale for the Super Bowl can cost around $38,000 to $54,000.

The most expensive airports for landing fees, based on a 767-400 aircraft, are primarily in Japan. Haneda Airport in Tokyo leads with a fee of £4,559 ($6,850), followed by Narita International Airport at £3,728 ($5,600), and Kansai International Airport in Osaka at £3,594 ($5,400). Other notable entries in the top 10 include Bristol Airport in the UK (£2,929 or $4,400), Dublin Airport in Ireland (£2,729 or $4,100), and Salzburg Airport in Austria (£2,530 or $3,800). 

The text underscores that while private jet travel is a luxury only the wealthy can afford, the high landing fees at these airports add to the substantial costs associated with this mode of transport.

Katie Gallegos, an animal lover and owner of Dogpatch Resort in Clackamas County, Oregon, took her Labrador, Cooper, and his smaller companion, Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy licked her treat slowly and daintily, Cooper swiftly consumed his ice cream cone in one bite, demonstrating his quick eating habit. The video of this event has garnered over seven million views, eliciting mixed reactions from viewers, some finding it cute and hilarious, while others criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs fast food. Gallegos defended her actions, stating that Cooper is an athletic dog in good health, and he occasionally enjoys an ice cream treat, similar to her late large breed mutt who lived to 19 years old. In contrast, Daisy, due to her size, only gets a few licks. The dogs' penchant for fast food is further evidenced by another video showing them at a Starbucks, where Cooper again consumes an entire 'pup-uccino' (whipped cream in a cup) in one go. Gallegos clarified that the Starbucks treat contains no coffee.

Gary Locke, the former Heart of Midlothian manager, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock on a three-year contract. He initially joined Kilmarnock as assistant to Allan Johnston last summer. Following Johnston's resignation in early February, Locke assumed the role of interim manager. During his interim period, Locke has demonstrated success, losing only once in his seven games. He is set to address the press regarding his new role in a conference on Friday morning.

Jessica Kemp, a mother from Eustis, Florida, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to the essential oils he wears to manage his condition. Kemp applies these oils, manufactured by Doterra, to Logan's head and neck to help him stay calm and focused. She claims Logan has been using these oils throughout the school year without issue until a teacher's aide complained about the scent being a distraction. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat of suspension, Kemp intends to continue using the oils, asserting their positive impact on her son. However, the Lake County School District later clarified they would not suspend Logan, categorizing it as a health issue. The oils used by the family include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex, the Sandpiper Complex in Westhampton Beach, was completely destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which began around 3 PM, spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby structures and could be seen from three miles away. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, they were unable to enter the building due to the strength of the flames. The cause of the fire is currently unknown but is being investigated, with initial claims suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper Complex is typically used as holiday homes by residents between May and November. Janice Sklarek, an owner, and Rob Taber, the building manager, both lost their homes and belongings in the incident. Fire Chief Ross Donneson noted that the offshore wind helped visibility but the fire's intensity made it challenging to control.

Queen Elizabeth II, approaching her 89th birthday, was seen enjoying a spring ride through Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma. Accompanied by a groom on another pony, the Queen appeared relaxed but, as usual, opted for a silk scarf over a riding helmet, citing her hair as the reason. The Queen, who has been riding since the age of four, is known for her lifelong love of horses. She first rode a Shetland pony named Peggy, a gift at age four. Over the years, she has ridden various horses, including Betsy and Surprise, the latter famously galloping down the Ascot course in 1961.

Despite a recent knee injury that has reduced her riding time, the Queen remains an enthusiastic equestrian. She breeds several breeds of horses and ponies, including Fell ponies, at Hampton Court and Balmoral. Fell ponies, one of the oldest equine breeds, are known for their docile, hardy nature and have been used for pack work and transportation since Roman times. The Queen's choice of Fell ponies reflects their popularity as family-friendly riding ponies.

A dispute over noise levels between two neighbors in North Brisbane ended tragically with the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman. The altercation occurred around 9 PM on a Thursday night when Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise in his yard on Muller Road. Phillip Pama, a 28-year-old Samoan married father of three and shift worker, confronted Yeaman, who was known for getting drunk, playing loud music, and yelling. During the confrontation, Pama allegedly struck Yeaman with a single punch, which proved fatal. Pama's defense lawyer stated that Pama was pushed while throwing the punch and didn't see it connect but felt it. Paramedics couldn't revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at the scene around 11 PM. Neighbors described Yeaman as kind and generous, while a friend noted he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed loud music. Pama, who has no prior violence history, was granted conditional bail with restrictions including surrendering his passport, adhering to a curfew, and regular police station visits. Pama, reportedly grief-stricken, is due back in court on May 18.

52-year-old music teacher Yulia Simonova was arrested in Shatura, Russia, after attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya. The relationship ended when Vanya left Simonova for a classmate. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (approximately £1,400) for the hit, detailing her desire for Vanya to suffer unbearable pain, including broken limbs and damaged kidneys, leading to a slow, painful death. The plan was foiled by an undercover police operation, with an officer posing as a hitman. Simonova was caught on hidden camera outlining her gruesome plans and was subsequently arrested. She now faces up to 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, relieved by the outcome, expressed hope that she would receive a severe sentence.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed in an interview with The Daily Telegraph that he maintains a strong faith in God, praying daily but not regularly attending church. He emphasizes that his conversations with God are strictly personal and never pertain to football. Mourinho, known for his intense demeanor on the sidelines, asserts he is a good person with no issues in his family or friend circles. He separates his professional and personal life, stating he never discusses football with his wife, Matilde Faria. Mourinho and his family have worked as ambassadors against hunger with the World Food Programme, highlighting their awareness of poverty. Despite his competitive and emotional professional environment, he believes a person's professional life is just a part of their overall identity. Currently, Chelsea is leading the league, and Mourinho was recently fined £25,000 for alleging a 'campaign' against Chelsea following a diving incident. The passage also mentions Mourinho's family, including his son Jose Mario, at various public events.

Bob Barker, the former long-time host of "The Price is Right," returned to the show on April 1, 2022, for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," looking energetic at age 91. Despite his long absence, Barker appeared to seamlessly resume his role, eventually handing over the hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in southeastern Washington D.C. at 12:30 AM on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house and damaging property. The incident occurred on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin, who is part of the foreign missions branch attached to the State Department, faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property. In response to the arrest, the Secret Service revoked his security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin was scheduled to be arraigned later that Friday, with no listed attorney. This incident follows another case where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave for alleged misconduct, both of which are under investigation by police and the Department of Homeland Security's Inspector General. These events add to recent controversies involving the agency, including an incident where two high-ranking officials were accused of driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, bravely ventured into Lahore Safari Park to capture images of a lion. Despite being only armed with a camera, Saeed crept within 10 feet of a hungry male lion, lying on the ground to get the perfect shot. The clicking sound of his camera's shutter alerted the lion, causing it to aggressively jump towards him. Saeed managed to scramble back into his car just in time, narrowly escaping the lion's attack. Initially laughing about the incident, Saeed later admitted he wouldn't repeat such a dangerous close encounter.

New York City police have released images of a distinctive tattoo found on an unidentified woman's leg, discovered unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 in Brooklyn's Gravesend section near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue. The tattoo, believed to be the name 'Monique' etched across a ribbon within a heart topped with a rose, is hoped to aid in identifying the woman, estimated to be between 25 and 45 years old. She was found without any identification. The medical examiner's report is still pending to determine the cause of death. The NYPD is urging anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers at 800-577-TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple who returned from the UK in 2009, built a unique home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck due to financial constraints. The project, a year and a half in the making, transformed the truck into a solar-powered, two-bedroom dwelling made of wood and steel. Located in Nelson, New Zealand, the home is surrounded by nature, featuring aromatic cypress wood interiors and majestic trees outside. It includes amenities like a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and a gas-powered hot water system. The water supply comes from a nearby spring, and the home is nearly self-sufficient, with their first electricity bill amounting to just $25. The total cost of the project was approximately $25,000. The couple, satisfied with their ingenious creation, even plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers from Northwestern University, led by Courtney Blackwell, have found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers in early literacy tests. The study, conducted over an academic year with 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district, revealed that shared iPad users scored approximately 30 points higher than those who used the devices individually or not at all. Blackwell attributes this success to "collaborative learning around the technology," suggesting that it's not just collaboration in general, but the specific interaction with technology that makes a difference. This finding contradicts the skepticism of the National Association of Head Teachers regarding the use of technology as a teaching aid in non-IT classes. Blackwell plans to present these findings at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico, potentially prompting schools to reconsider their approach to integrating tablets in early education.

A piglet born without back legs in Qionglai city, Sichuan province, China, has gained internet fame for learning to walk on its front trotters. The farmer, Ms. Duan, noticed the piglet's condition when it was feeding. Despite the challenge, the piglet has mastered balancing and foraging, often seen wobbling but always regaining its balance. It interacts well with its fully-legged siblings. The heartwarming video of its progress has captivated thousands online. This isn't the first instance of a two-legged animal in China; a rabbit in Guangxi province also gained popularity for walking on its front paws. Both animals have drawn significant local and online attention.

On Sunday, during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dayle Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Drake's car. Drake was coming in for tires and fuel on lap 25 and spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center where he received stitches for a cut on his leg and was later released. Drake did not finish the race and ended up 23rd. The race saw many cars struggling with traction due to hours of rainfall before the green flag.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, after four days of marriage. The incident was captured on CCTV footage, showing Severiano dragging de Sena's limp body into their apartment's garden, then repeatedly smashing her head into concrete 11 times and punching her face another 10 times. He subsequently returned with a handgun and shot her five times at point-blank range. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy over men looking at his wife was the motive. De Sena, known by her stage name Amanda Bueno, was a member of the dance troupe Jaula das Gostozuedas. Neighbors reported hearing a terrible argument and accusations of infidelity before the gunshots. Severiano fled the scene in a stolen car but was apprehended after crashing it. Police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in the vehicle. He now faces life in prison for the murder.

Sarah Wilson, a 41-year-old journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," has disclosed her personal struggle with mental illness, specifically anxiety and depression. In a candid interview with Women's Weekly Australia, she revealed that her anxiety once led her to contemplate suicide, as she felt she couldn't see the point of continuing due to mounting stress, her thyroid disease, and feelings of isolation. Wilson described her younger years as challenging, feeling increasingly alone and as if she had "missed out on a guidebook to life" while watching others cope more easily. She now identifies as an "anxious person" and believes anxiety and depression are intrinsically linked. Wilson emphasizes the need to acknowledge this connection to better address the rising rates of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. She notes that anxiety is becoming the "new depression," citing a Beyond Blue report that one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime. Despite her past struggles, Wilson has found some peace and currently advocates for mental health awareness. She encourages those in need to reach out to support services like Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault in November 2014 after she attacked her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar. The incident occurred when Curtin found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom. Despite refusing to leave when asked, Curtin struck her with a crowbar. Prosecutors dropped the charges on Monday, deeming Curtin's actions "completely justified in her outrage" due to Oregon law allowing physical force against intruders who refuse to leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney, Casey Kovacic, stated that the ex-girlfriend had been harassing and threatening Curtin for two years, including plotting to rekindle her boyfriend's heroin addiction. The ex-girlfriend and Curtin's boyfriend, the father of Curtin's child, have since reconciled, though the boyfriend has not been involved in his new child's life. If convicted, Curtin could have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years. Curtin gave birth in January following the dropped charges.

Gemma, a pit bull from California, was filmed by her owner while being fed treats. In an attempt to trick her, the owner included a piece of broccoli. Gemma displayed an immediate dislike for the vegetable, pulling a disgusted face and spitting it out on the floor. The article humorously hopes that the two children she lives with won't mimic her aversion to broccoli. When not rejecting vegetables, Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized for a significant blunder on its official website. A link on the page for the now-defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards directed visitors to a pornographic site. This occurred because the address for the awards page, which was shut down in 2011, was allowed to retire and was subsequently taken over by the adult content site. The bank removed the hyperlink after discovering the mistake, emphasizing they have no association with the external site. HSBC assured the public that their internet banking services, which include account management, fund transfers, loan applications, and insurance, remain secure. The bank issued a formal apology for any inconvenience caused.

A 13-year-old boy named Marcus from Maryland made a 911 call after a fire broke out in his family's home in Clinton on Sunday morning. Marcus and his 9-year-old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second-floor bedroom due to the intense heat in the hallway. Despite the situation, Marcus remained calm throughout the 11-minute call, providing detailed instructions to the dispatcher. He reassured his sister, who was distressed, telling her to stay low and breathe. Marcus guided the emergency services to their location, directing them to a black door in the back hallway. Prince George's County firefighters rescued the siblings by breaking a window and handing Marcus out to another rescuer. Lieutenant Kenny Ward then gave his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The other family members, including Marcus' older brother, mother, and stepfather, escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae, known as Noctiluca scintillans, has been captured in stunning images along Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the scene as a "beautiful supernatural" phenomenon, caused by millions of plankton emitting light. A similar event occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers, an oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, explained that Noctiluca scintillans, a single-celled phytoplankton, blooms in spring and autumn, often due to natural causes. This carnivorous algae preys on diatoms and emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism. Suthers reassured that the algae bloom is typically harmless.

New genetic tests are enabling breast cancer patients to potentially avoid chemotherapy by identifying'markers' in tumors that determine the disease's aggressiveness. After surgery, cancer cells are analyzed in a lab to assess the risk of recurrence within days. For some women, the test can accurately predict a low risk, as low as 5%, which is comparable to or better than the odds for those who undergo chemotherapy. 

Currently, most breast cancer patients receive chemotherapy post-surgery to prevent recurrence, despite the severe side effects such as hair loss, nausea, fatigue, and weight changes. However, experts have long believed that the risk of recurrence varies among women, and chemotherapy may not be necessary for some.

One such test, called Endopredict, can provide a low score, allowing patients to opt out of chemotherapy. While these tests are currently available privately at around £2,500, breast specialists hope they will soon be accessible on the NHS. Surgeon Hemant Singhal suggests the NHS should consider using this test, citing potential savings from not administering chemotherapy.

Professor Kefah Mokbel, a consultant breast surgeon, emphasizes that these tests empower patients to make informed decisions, unlike the previous standard of administering chemotherapy to almost all patients.

Becca Cornford, a 49-year-old mother of three, exemplifies the impact of these tests. After being diagnosed and treated for breast cancer, she feared chemotherapy more than another mastectomy due to its potential interference with her ability to care for her children. Professor Mokbel tested her tumor using Endopredict, revealing a 5% risk of recurrence over ten years. Given that chemotherapy could not significantly improve these odds, Becca decided against it, opting instead for regular monitoring.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy over the past nine years, as revealed by a Freedom of Information request. HMS Ocean alone saw five pregnant sailors removed in emergency evacuations. Other ships involved include HMS Illustrious, HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond. A strict "no touching" rule on board suggests most pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. 

The data also emerges nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first female warship captain, was flown back to the UK following allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member. An investigation was launched, and she was replaced by an unnamed captain for "personal reasons," which the MoD did not disclose.

Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, making up around 9% of personnel in 2014. In May of the previous year, three women became the first female submariners in the Royal Navy. 

Comparably, nearly 100 British female soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy between 2006 and 2013, with 16 removed in 2013 and 18 in 2011. A further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving in war zones, and they are flown back on flights typically reserved for injured troops. Most pregnancies are likely conceived before deployment, though a small number may have occurred during service.

A radioactive drone was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The drone, approximately 20 inches wide, contained traces of cesium, a byproduct of nuclear reactors, along with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle. The discovery was made on the same day a Japanese court approved the restart of two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a decision met with public opposition due to safety concerns following the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga warned of possible future terrorism attempts using drones during the Olympics and G7 summit. Currently, there are no flight restrictions for drones in most of Tokyo, including around government buildings. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was not present at the time as he was in Indonesia for an Asian-African conference. The amount of cesium found is not immediately harmful to humans.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang Province, China, has garnered attention for his dedication to caring for his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease. Fearing she might get lost due to her condition, Lu brings her to work on the back of his motorbike daily. He ties a sash around their waists for safety and ensures they travel slowly so she feels comfortable and they can converse. His mother, who once devoted her life to caring for her children, now resides in a room provided by his employer, a bank. Lu's commitment stems from the absence of other caregivers; his wife works in a different city, and his son is in school. Lu emphasizes his duty to reciprocate his mother's lifelong care, stating, "I was an apple in my mum's eye, and now she's my apple."

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, reveals a significant rise in heavy and binge drinking among Americans between 2005 and 2012. Heavy drinking increased by 17.2%, primarily due to rising rates among women. The study defines heavy drinking as exceeding one drink per day for women and two for men over the past month, and binge drinking as four or more drinks for women and five for men on a single occasion at least once in the past month.

The increase in binge drinking among women is nearly three times the rate among men, with women's binge drinking rates in Santa Clara County, California, rising by 36% between 2002 and 2012. Nationwide, women's binge drinking rates increased more than seven times the rate among men. In 2012, 18% of Americans were binge drinkers, and 8% were considered heavy drinkers. Despite these increases, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively stable.

The study, the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, found significant variations across the country, with Madison County, Idaho, reporting the lowest binge drinking rate (6%) and Menominee, Wisconsin, the highest (36%). Similarly, Hancock County, Tennessee, had the fewest heavy drinkers (2%), while Esmeralda County, Nevada, had the most (22%).

Experts attribute the rise in excessive drinking to changing social norms, making it more socially acceptable for women to drink like men, increased affluence allowing for more drinking, and the influx of wealthy professionals in cities like San Francisco, San Jose, and Oakland. Additionally, real-term decreases in alcohol taxes, increased advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies are cited as contributing factors. In 2010, about 88,600 U.S. deaths were attributed to alcohol, and the economic cost of excessive drinking was estimated at over $220 billion annually.

UN officials from the World Health Organization (WHO) warn that doctors in England are performing caesarean sections too frequently, putting women and their babies at risk. The caesarean rate in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, currently standing at just over a quarter of all births. This includes a growing number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural childbirth. However, WHO recommends the rate should ideally be between 10% and 15%. They caution that caesareans, while life-saving, can lead to infections, disabilities, or even death when performed without medical necessity. The procedure also diverts resources from other patient needs, with a planned caesarean costing the NHS £2,369 compared to £1,665 for a natural birth. Current NHS guidelines, as per Nice's 2011 recommendations, allow caesareans for women with severe childbirth anxiety (tokophobia) or previous complicated births, advanced age, or certain medical conditions. WHO's statement contradicts these guidelines, emphasizing that doctors are underestimating the risks associated with unnecessary caesareans.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for allegedly breaking into a $800,000 summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard. She lived inside the property for at least a week, claiming ownership when confronted by the owner, Mark Conklin. Filkins was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after Conklin discovered her in his living room. She fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when he called the police. 

Upon arrival, police found a broken window and later arrested Filkins when she attempted to re-enter the house, believing Conklin had left. A neighborhood construction worker reported seeing Filkins selling or giving away items from the home, including a Weber grill, deck chairs, lamps, pots, pans, linens, and a painting. The police are asking anyone who received these items to return them to the Edgartown Police Department, offering assistance in seeking restitution. Filkins is next scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke, a Melbourne resident, lost her unlocked iPhone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border the following morning. Realizing the phone was unlocked, police officers used it to post humorous selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the station on Bella's Facebook page. They also posted witty messages, such as "when you're ready to pick it up, it will be at Albury Police Station" and "if your worried about the battery going flat, don't... by the time you pick it up it will be fully 'charged'." 

The posts gained traction among Bella's friends, who praised the police for their creative approach. By the time Bella arrived at the police station, the posts had already amused her and her friends. Upon her arrival, officers recognized her from her Facebook page and didn't require her to provide identification. Bella was able to retrieve her phone without any hassle, and she appreciated the police's sense of humor. She has since secured her phone with a password. The entire process was documented and shared, highlighting the successful and entertaining reunion of the lost iPhone with its owner.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was tragically killed in a fight between two adult males at the Isimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The incident occurred when the calf strayed into the conflict zone. The calf's mother, who had been protectively chasing away younger hippos, watched in horror as the baby was grabbed by one of the adults between its jaws. Despite her attempts to retrieve her calf, the sub-adult hippo tightened its grip, and the mother's aggressive reaction resulted in the baby being thrown into the air. The calf sustained severe injuries and died hours later. Tour operator Stacey Farrell, who witnessed the event, noted the uncertainty of whether the act was intentional or a result of play or jealousy gone wrong.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, one of the most expensive areas to live in Britain, is on the market for £575,000. However, the property comes with a significant catch: it has only three years left on its lease. This would equate to an annual cost of £191,000 or £15,000 per month, roughly the going rate for renting a similar property in the area. The 1,990 sq/ft maisonette, described as 'bright and well proportioned', features three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. 

Despite its current state (unmodernized and in need of renovation), if the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The next cheapest three-bedroom property in Knightsbridge, with a 28-year lease, costs £1.5 million. The property is being sold by Russell Simpson and has generated substantial interest from locals, developers, and end-users. 

The freeholder is believed to be the Welcome Trust, and extending the lease would likely cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million for a 90-year extension. Estate agents note that properties with such short leases rarely come up for sale, but potential buyers are warned about the substantial premium required to extend the lease, making it a 'quirky situation'.

Starbucks experienced a nationwide computer outage on Friday evening that affected 8,000 stores across the U.S. and Canada, causing registers to malfunction. This led baristas to offer free drinks and baked goods to customers. The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. It was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, according to Starbucks' statement. The company apologized for the inconvenience and stated that stores would resume normal operations the following day. Despite the free giveaway, some stores closed early or entirely to avoid giving away free products. The incident occurred just a day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with shares rising 4.4% to $51.50 following the announcement.

Terrorists are reportedly undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit. These activities are often disguised as ordinary community involvement, but they serve a radicalization purpose. The issue of terrorism is not confined to urban areas, as evidenced by incidents dating back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. 

The rugged terrain of these areas, used by the British military for training, has also attracted terrorists. For instance, two of the 7/7 London bombers were photographed white water rafting in Bala, North Wales. In 2010, three Cardiff men were arrested for plotting an 'Mumbai-style' terror attack, linked to an al-Qaeda inspiration. 

Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences in Highmead, near Llanybydder, reportedly set up by Iraqi clerics. Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, and Abdul Miah, who were part of a terror plot, were also photographed in secret meetings in a Welsh country park. 

Jones emphasized the importance of community intelligence, stating that authorities must consider any information coming from the community, as these activities often involve individuals participating in seemingly normal community activities with hidden motives.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct and rarely sighted, was discovered on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia following Tropical Cyclone Olwyn. This marks the first sighting in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Initially, the identification of the 5.68m whale was challenging for Department of Parks and Wildlife staff, but DNA profiling confirmed it to be an Omura's whale. Environment Minister Albert Jacob described the find as "highly significant" due to the limited knowledge about this species, which was first documented in scientific journals in 2003. Omura's whales are typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, and are characterized by their sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried, with plans to recover the skeleton in a few years for further scientific study and potential public display in museums. This discovery will aid in improving field identification and understanding the whale's regional distribution.

The passage discusses the controversial viewpoint of Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, who believes that Hillary Clinton should not be president due to the potential impact of her hormones on decision-making, specifically starting unnecessary wars. Rios argues that women's hormones make them unfit for leadership roles, a perspective that has drawn significant criticism. The article counters this by citing studies showing women leaders take fewer risks than men, and references historical examples of male politicians' poor decisions influenced by hormones.

The debate extends beyond Rios, reflecting a broader societal bias against women in leadership. Despite women outnumbering men in higher education and the workforce, gender bias persists, limiting women's potential. This bias is evident in overt ways, like the underrepresentation of women on corporate boards, and covert ways, such as gendered descriptions of professors.

The text also highlights the potential benefits of gender equality, noting that companies with more women in leadership roles are more profitable, children with involved fathers are healthier, and diverse teams produce better results. The article concludes by emphasizing that while society encourages daughters to dream big, it's crucial to also affirm their potential despite societal biases and stereotypes. The piece corrects a previous statement, noting that Canada elected its first female Prime Minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and multiple portrayals of Winston Churchill, is auctioning off his extensive collection of antiques valued at £100,000. The 89-year-old, a military history enthusiast and former student of J.R.R. Tolkien, is downsizing his home and collection. The auction, held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire, includes over 200 items such as furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. 

Among the highlights are a hand-painted limewood diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, commissioned from artist L.M. Rendall in the 1960s, estimated to fetch £4,000 to £6,000, and a longbow with a mother-of-pearl handle, expected to sell for up to £2,000. The collection also features a portrait of Hardy holding a longbow, reflecting his expertise in medieval history. 

Hardy, who has published books on the history of the longbow and was consulted during the raising of the Mary Rose, expressed sadness over downsizing but hopes the new owners will find joy in his possessions. The auction comprises 238 lots, including dozens of 17th-century books and an early 20th-century painting of Alfred the Great. Despite his retirement from stage acting due to a fall, Hardy plans to continue television work.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a resident of Winter Garden, Florida, is currently a fugitive after being named as a suspect in his mother Sandra Shemansky's murder. Sandra, 57, was found dead at their shared home on Saturday, following a well-being check request from an out-of-state family member. An initial investigation indicated foul play. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day, drawing police attention.

Shemansky has a history of mental health issues, including bipolar disorder, and was previously involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward after an attempted suicide. He is currently on parole for battery on law enforcement. His estranged wife had filed a domestic violence injunction against him two years ago.

Neighbors suggest that the stress from ongoing divorce proceedings, coupled with recent bad news received on Friday, may have triggered the murder. One neighbor reported seeing Shemansky entering the trailer park's office for water shortly after the murder. He was last spotted fleeing on foot without provisions or medication.

Authorities possess the murder weapon but have not disclosed the method of killing. Shemansky's estranged wife is preparing for potential self-defense if he returns. Anyone with information about his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities at 407-656-3636.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council has awarded Eugene, Oregon, USA, the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made without a bidding process, as the IAAF saw it as a "unique strategic opportunity" to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously unsuccessfully bid for the 2019 event, which was instead awarded to Doha, Qatar. IAAF President Lamine Diack emphasized the strategic importance of this decision, highlighting the collaboration between public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC, and the enthusiastic local public. This choice deviates from the usual procedure but is seen as beneficial for the global development of athletics. Notably, the 2007 IAAF World Championships in Osaka, Japan, was also awarded without a bidding process. The passage also mentions Mo Farah's gold medal win in the men's 10000 meters at the 2013 IAAF World Athletics Championships in Moscow.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, from Gillingham, Kent, has been sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56. Granger lured Hassan, whom she met at a London casino, by using her charm and befriending him, showering her with gifts, cash, and lavish outings. On the night of the incident, she invited her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, 28, and his accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, 29, to Hassan's flat after leaving him there. The two men tied up Hassan, brutally beat him to death, and ransacked his home in search of his hidden winnings, leaving him with multiple broken bones and drowning in his own blood.

Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not murder by a majority verdict at the Old Bailey. She was described as "deceitful from the outset" by Judge William Kennedy, who noted her involvement was driven by her love for Jackson and his persuasive influence. Co-defendants Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. They were also convicted of additional charges including robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison Hassan.

The prosecution highlighted Hassan's vulnerability as a professional gambler who kept large sums of cash at home, making him an easy target. The attack was described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge, reflecting the brutal nature of the crime. The case also involved two failed armed robberies at a different casino earlier in the year, orchestrated by Jackson and Chandler. The trio was caught after Granger's phone records were examined, revealing them throwing Hassan's stolen money around post-murder. Hassan's family expressed their grief, stating his death will "haunt them forever."

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has been experiencing a noticeable decline in form during the second half of the season, as highlighted in Spain's 2-0 defeat to the Netherlands. Despite his earlier happiness at Chelsea and a promising start to the season, Fabregas' performance has significantly dropped. He was rated only four out of ten by a Spanish newspaper in the recent match. Although Chelsea is likely to secure the Premier League title, concerns about Fabregas' durability persist. His fatigue from a long, intense campaign is evident, as seen in his struggles during Spain's match in Amsterdam. 

Fabregas, who captained Spain, failed to make a significant impact in midfield against Holland. His form slump aligns with a pattern observed at Barcelona, where his contributions decreased as each season progressed. This trend is reflected in his assist statistics; while he had 15 assists by mid-January, he has only managed one in his subsequent five games. 

Fabregas' late-season slump has put him at risk of falling short of Thierry Henry's Premier League record of 20 assists, set in the 2002-03 season. However, with nine games left in the Premier League, including matches against teams he has previously provided assists to, there's still a chance for him to regain form and help Chelsea secure the title. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is hopeful for a late-season resurgence from Fabregas, crucial for the team's push towards the Premier League title.

West Ham United is in negotiations to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a trial period with the club's academy. Beckford, hailing from Montego Bay United, spent two weeks training with West Ham and has caught the attention of coaches. He has also received offers from clubs in Belgium and has been linked with several European teams, making him one of the most promising prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets for the 2016-17 season at their new Olympic Stadium will start from £289, aiming to fill the 54,000 capacity venue with the cheapest pricing strategy in the Premier League.

Wiltshire police have discontinued their investigation into the violent assault of Mike Lane, a 40-year-old huntsman, just three months after the incident. The attack occurred on January 24 at Everleigh, near Amesbury, where Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters wielding iron bars on ropes. Despite a video of the incident and a dossier containing evidence like names of saboteurs and car registration numbers, police claim insufficient evidence to identify and prosecute the attackers.

Lane, who suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss, criticized the police decision as "pathetic" and expressed loss of trust in law enforcement. The attack happened despite the hunt only chasing an artificial scent, not a fox. During the confrontation, Lane was knocked to the ground, kicked in the head, and struck with a rope-bound iron bar.

Karen Fieldsend, who reported the incident to the police, and James Cameron, vice-chairman of the Tedworth Hunt, also expressed disappointment and frustration with the police's decision. The Countryside Alliance is advocating for a ban on saboteurs wearing face coverings to facilitate justice. Wiltshire police stated that the case is currently recorded as "undetected," but could be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, also known as "Azzam the American," was a prominent American member of Al-Qaeda, serving as its chief English-language propagandist. Born in 1978 in California, he converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 1998, where he joined Al-Qaeda. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to Al-Qaeda. Gadahn appeared in numerous Al-Qaeda videos, threatening attacks on the U.S. and Western targets, and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was known for his criticism of U.S. presidents and his calls for lone-wolf attacks by Muslims in the U.S. using easily obtainable firearms. 

The White House announced in January 2021 that Gadahn was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation, though he was not specifically targeted. His death occurred in a separate operation from that which killed another U.S. citizen and Al-Qaeda operative, Ahmed Farouq, and Italian hostage Giovanni Lo Porto. Gadahn's last video was posted in September 2014, where he called for overthrowing governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to a woman from Afghanistan and had at least one child.

A five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo is gaining viral fame for his exceptional basketball skills, as showcased in a video that has circulated widely across China. Mai began practicing basketball at the age of two and a half. The video displays him scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously without losing rhythm. His talent has earned him numerous fans and admiration, with netizens expressing shock and awe. Some comments reflect disbelief, questioning if the video is enhanced with special effects, while others express feelings of inadequacy compared to his skills. Mai's prowess has sparked discussions and comparisons to China's most renowned basketball star, Yao Ming, who played for the NBA's Houston Rockets from 2002 to 2011.

Tom O'Carroll, a prominent figure in the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), a group that advocated for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has become a supporter of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and key PIE activist, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25. The rally aimed to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established in response to the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation (IPSO) and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as suggested by the Leveson Inquiry. 

O'Carroll's association with Hacked Off is likely to cause embarrassment for the group. PIE, founded in 1974, campaigned for the legalization of sex with children and even sought to lower the age of consent to ten if the child "understood the nature of the act." The National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), of which O'Carroll was part of the gay rights sub-committee, also lobbied for such changes. O'Carroll was imprisoned in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." He confirmed his attendance at the February meeting, chaired by comedian John Cleese, in a subsequent blog post. A Hacked Off spokesperson stated that the meeting was open to the public.

On Thursday, Bondi's iconic Icebergs Club pool was drained to serve as an unconventional catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event, hosted by lifestyle brand Ten Pieces led by restaurateur Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome capsule collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall, with the ocean serving as a stunning backdrop. The presentation attracted crowds both from the club's balcony and passers-by, who stopped to watch from the road above. Despite the disruption to regular lap swimmers, the event was held on an unusually warm 28 degrees Celsius day, with guests enjoying food from Icebergs and drinks from Santa Vittoria. The androgynous designs, suitable for day-to-night wear, were well-received under the beautiful blue sky.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan and his family, including his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, enjoyed a day trip to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, a safari park in Northern California. During their visit, Khan posed for photos and fed a rare white tiger, as well as interacted with giraffes and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about potential bouts with British rival Kell Brook and other boxers like Adrien Broner and Keith Thurman.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His name was mistakenly included on a memorial wall at Jerusalem's Mount Herzl, which honors fallen Israeli soldiers and victims of terrorism. Abu Khdeir's family and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror, objected to his inclusion, arguing it was a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. Almagor's CEO, Meir Indor, demanded the removal of Abu Khdeir's name, stating they would also remove their own family members' names if necessary. Following the family's complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel agreed to remove his name from the memorial. The three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing are currently undergoing a trial, with hearings beginning in January.

California-based YouTube user Lionel Hutz captured his young son attempting to use their family cat as a pillow. The footage shows the boy chasing the cat around the garden, then gently placing his head on the cat's belly. The cat, initially licking its fur, tolerates this for a brief moment before getting up and moving to another spot. The boy follows, repeating the process twice more. Eventually, the cat had enough and went indoors. Despite the initial playful resistance, a later video shows the duo reconciled, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia is ongoing, but a witness, Robert Kushner, has already faced consequences for his testimony. Kushner, 32, lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after admitting to years of marijuana dealing. He is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, alleging police wrongdoing. Kushner claimed that some undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, which he stated was expunged as part of a probationary sentence. However, he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation, and also pleaded guilty to a 2008 DUI. Kushner maintains his innocence in the 2011 charges and expresses remorse for deceiving the school, where he passed a background check in 2010. He continues to coach in a Narberth summer league, where he is highly regarded. The defense lawyers for the six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering argue that the government's case is based on testimonies from 19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province, China, caused a large fire, injuring six people, five of whom were treated for glass injuries. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility following an oil leak, though no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters managed to control the blaze. The incident has sparked concerns due to the plant's history of accidents and protests over pollution fears. In 2007, the plant was initially planned for Xiamen but was relocated to its current site due to public backlash. The plant had a previous explosion in July 2013, also without casualties or toxic leaks. Despite demonstrations being illegal in China, the construction of PX plants has led to protests in various cities.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa's young player, has defiantly stated he won't change his sock-wearing habit despite criticism from Premier League referees. Known for wearing his socks just above his shinpads, Grealish attributes this to superstition. He uses children's-sized shinpads, which might initially appear as not wearing them. Grealish made his first Premier League start in Aston Villa's 3-3 draw against QPR, a tough match in a relegation battle. Despite the challenging game's outcome, Grealish is pleased to have earned his start and hopes for more opportunities under the manager's faith in him. He remains undeterred by referees' attempts to correct his sock style, asserting he hasn't had a kick on his shin yet and hopes to keep it that way.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22-year-old daughter of Bobby Brown and the late Whitney Houston, is reported to have "global and irreversible brain damage," according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite no longer being in a medically induced coma, Bobbi Kristina remains unresponsive to visitors and familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow movement. She has a tracheostomy and remains in the same neurological state she's been in for nearly three months. 

Bobby Brown recently stated that his daughter's condition had improved, claiming she was awake and watching him. However, an attorney for the Brown family, Christopher Brown, clarified that while doctors predict a long life for Bobbi Kristina, the quality of her life remains uncertain and she is currently undergoing a lengthy rehabilitation process. The discrepancy in reports highlights the emotional state of the family during this challenging time.

Russia is on the verge of securing a spot in the Fed Cup final after leading Germany 2-0. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point against Sabine Lisicki, ultimately winning 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3. Earlier, Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Both players struggled with their serves; Pavlyuchenkova committed 13 double faults, while Lisicki made 63 unforced errors, which were pivotal in her loss. Russia now needs just one win from Sunday's three matches to clinch their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still recovering from last week's severe weather, are being warned of another impending storm expected to bring more floods and damage later in the week. Meteorologists predict an east coast low, similar to the system that battered the state's east coast for three days last week, could return, causing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. 

The State Emergency Service (SES) is currently overwhelmed with cleanup efforts from the previous storm, with over 4,000 of 24,196 requests still unfulfilled. SES spokeswoman Stephanie Wills expressed concern that additional storms could further hinder these efforts, particularly in the hard-hit Hunter region, which experienced significant flooding and high winds. 

Wills emphasized the need for residents to prepare themselves, their homes, and families to prevent further loss and devastation. Meteorologist Kim Westcott noted that a trough of low pressure is forming along the coast, expected to impact the far northern parts of the state the most. Unlike the previous storm, this system is predicted to move quickly, likely bringing two days of rain rather than three. 

Bureau of Meteorology NSW regional director Barry Hanstrum stated that the main impacts will be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, including the Northern Rivers and Mid North Coasts, with heavy falls also likely for southeast Queensland. Further rainfall is anticipated for catchments that have already experienced flooding during the previous severe weather event. 

The SES is working to complete as many pending jobs as possible before the next storm hits, with over 1000 personnel, including 200 from other states, currently in the field across NSW.

Nina Moric, a 38-year-old model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" music video, has refuted claims that she attempted suicide. According to Italian media, Moric was found by her mother in their Milan apartment and was hospitalized due to an alleged suicide attempt. However, Moric clarified on her Instagram, which has over 40,000 followers, that she did not try to take her own life. Instead, she collapsed due to low blood pressure after a domestic accident where she fell and hit her head, resulting in bruises all over her body. Moric stated she was recovering at home and was "shocked" by the suicide claims. Her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, was reportedly in Naples at the time of the incident. This isn't the first time Moric has faced such rumors; Italian media also claimed she tried to commit suicide in 2009 by overdose. Moric, born in Croatia, was previously married to Italian paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria. Corona was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos.

Kate and William, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, are preparing for the arrival of their second child, with the British public eagerly anticipating a traditional name. According to a YouGov poll for The Sunday Times, if the baby is a girl, Diana, named after William's mother, the late Princess of Wales, is the top choice, favored by 12% of those polled. Alice and Charlotte follow with 9% each; Alice is the name of the Queen's aunt, and Charlotte honors William's father, Charles. If the baby is a boy, James and Alexander are the preferred names. A quarter of the 2,200 people surveyed hope for a girl, while only 3% wish for a brother for Prince George. The public's preference for Diana as a girl's name is also reflected on social media. Additionally, 68% of respondents support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, resulting in 17 deaths and over 64 injuries, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon. The incident occurred around 10 a.m. local time as the protesters were en route to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. Taliban spokesman Zabiullah Mujahid denied the group's involvement, and no other organization has claimed responsibility yet. CNN's Masoud Popalzai reported from Kabul, with additional contributions from Jethro Mullen in Hong Kong and Elizabeth Joseph.

Dani Alves, the 31-year-old Brazilian right-back, is set to depart Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. His representative, Dinorah Santana (his ex-wife), confirmed this at a press conference, stating that negotiations are over. The offer was a three-year extension contingent on Alves participating in 60% of the club's matches. Despite a successful seven-year stint at Barcelona, where he won four Spanish titles and two Champions Leagues, Alves couldn't agree to the terms. His potential departure comes as a surprise, given Barcelona's lack of progress in contract discussions until April.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old striker currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian football legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo, who has scored three goals in six games for Boca, believes both players would fit well in the team due to their South American-style play. He suggests that the fans would adore having Pirlo and Totti on the La Bombonera pitch. Pirlo, renowned as one of the best midfielders globally, and Totti, a Roma legend, are both highly respected in world football. Osvaldo, having played with many great players, specifically chose Pirlo and Totti, stating they would be perfect for Boca Juniors.

Eighteen-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson experienced a dramatic fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the spectacular double somersault, Ferguson only sustained a minor cut on his nose. The fall, which has been viewed hundreds of thousands of times online, did not deter him from his duties. He returned to mucking out stables at Paul Nicholls' yard the following morning. Ferguson described the incident as a blur, only realizing the extent of the fall upon watching the replay. His fellow jockeys expressed concern and shared the replay with him. Despite receiving some online abuse, Ferguson took the situation lightly, even jokingly considering a career in gymnastics due to his acrobatic fall.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain and England flanker, joined the hype for the new "Avengers: Age of Ultron" movie release. He posted a photo on Instagram dressed as Iron Man, Robert Downey Jr.'s character, along with a caption expressing his excitement about the movie. Haskell originally started his career with London Wasps in 2002, earning his first England cap five years later. He left Wasps in 2009 for stints in France (Stade Francais), Japan (Ricoh Black Rams), and New Zealand (Highlanders), but returned to Wasps in 2012, surpassing 100 appearances for the club. Since his return, he has also become a significant member of the England squad, earning 57 caps.

The passage discusses the resurgence of wide-leg trousers in Spring/Summer 2015 (SS15) trends, marking a shift away from the long-dominant skinny jean style. Louise Redknapp endorses this trend, noting its refreshing change and versatility. The wide-leg trouser, which has cycled back since the 1970s, can be found in various forms such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped. 

Despite potential intimidation, especially for those who are shorter, the key to styling wide-leg trousers is in the choice of footwear and upper body attire. High heels, particularly those with an exposed top of the foot, are recommended to elongate the leg. Pairing wide-leg trousers with simple knits or basic tops helps maintain a current, cool look. 

High-waisted, long versions are suggested for added leg length. Denim is identified as the easiest way to adopt this trend, with Gucci's SS15 collection featuring vintage-washed flared jeans.
